Born in 1933, Old's academic journey led him to study under Karl Barth at the University of Basel, where he honed his theological acumen. His magnum opus, the multi-volume 'The Reading and Preaching of the Scriptures in the Worship of the Christian Church,' is a monumental contribution that traces the evolution of preaching from the early church to the modern era. Old's scholarship was characterized by a meticulous examination of primary sources, and he engaged critically with the works of Augustine, Calvin, and Barth, among others. His work often intersected with liturgical studies, emphasizing the centrality of Scripture in worship. Old was a staunch advocate for the recovery of classical Reformed liturgical practices, arguing for their relevance in contemporary worship settings. His contributions to the understanding of the theological underpinnings of preaching have been influential in both academic and ecclesiastical circles. Despite his traditionalist leanings, Old was not without controversy, particularly in his critique of modern liturgical innovations, which he viewed as departures from historical orthodoxy. His legacy endures through his writings and the generations of students he mentored at institutions like Princeton Theological Seminary.

timeline.event: Studied under Karl Barth at University of Basel
Published first volume of 'The Reading and Preaching of the Scriptures'

themes.label: History of Preaching
themes.gloss: Old's comprehensive study of preaching spans from the early church to contemporary times, emphasizing the continuity and evolution of homiletic practices.

themes.label: Reformed Liturgical Practices
themes.gloss: He advocated for the recovery and application of classical Reformed liturgical elements, arguing for their theological and spiritual significance in modern worship.

themes.label: Scripture in Worship
themes.gloss: Old emphasized the centrality of Scripture in worship, critiquing modern practices that he felt undermined this foundational aspect of Reformed theology.

name: Norman Shepherd
bio: Norman Shepherd is a contemporary Reformed theologian known for his controversial views on justification and covenant theology. Born in 1933, Shepherd served as a professor of systematic theology at Westminster Theological Seminary from 1963 to 1981. His tenure at Westminster was marked by significant theological debate, particularly concerning his views on the relationship between faith and works in justification. Shepherd's position, which suggested a more integrated role of works within the covenantal framework of salvation, sparked intense controversy and led to his departure from the seminary. His interlocutors included prominent Reformed theologians such as Cornelius Van Til and John Murray, who influenced his theological development. Shepherd's contributions are encapsulated in his works such as 'The Call of Grace: How the Covenant Illuminates Salvation and Evangelism,' where he articulates his covenantal perspective. His theological stance has been both critiqued and defended within Reformed circles, contributing to ongoing discussions about the nature of the covenant and the doctrine of justification. Shepherd's legacy continues to provoke dialogue on the interplay between faith, works, and assurance within the Reformed tradition.

timeline.event: Departed Westminster Theological Seminary amid controversy.
Published 'The Call of Grace' articulating his covenantal theology.

themes.label: Justification and Works
themes.gloss: Shepherd challenged traditional Reformed views by proposing that works play a more integral role in justification, emphasizing a covenantal framework that includes obedience as a necessary component of faith.

themes.label: Covenant Theology
themes.gloss: Shepherd's theology is marked by a distinctive understanding of the covenant, where he argues for a holistic view that sees the covenant as central to understanding salvation history and the believer's relationship with God.

themes.label: Faith and Assurance
themes.gloss: Shepherd's views on faith and assurance suggest that assurance is not merely a subjective feeling but is grounded in the covenantal promises of God, with an emphasis on the believer's faithful response.

name: Eberhard JÃ¼ngel
bio: Eberhard JÃ¼ngel was a prominent German theologian known for his contributions to contemporary theology, particularly within the neo-orthodox tradition. Born in 1934, JÃ¼ngel studied under Karl Barth at the University of Basel, which significantly influenced his theological trajectory. His work is characterized by a profound engagement with the dialectical theology of Barth, while also incorporating elements of existential philosophy, particularly the thought of Martin Heidegger. JÃ¼ngel's seminal work, 'God as the Mystery of the World,' explores the relationship between God's self-revelation and human understanding, emphasizing the paradoxical nature of divine mystery. He was a critical interlocutor with Rudolf Bultmann, engaging with the latter's demythologization project, yet diverging in his insistence on the historical reality of the resurrection. JÃ¼ngel's theology is marked by a robust Christocentrism, arguing that God's being is constituted in the act of self-giving love, a concept he elaborates in 'The Doctrine of the Trinity: God's Being is in Becoming.' His engagement with the doctrine of justification reflects a deep commitment to the Lutheran tradition, yet he reinterprets it in light of contemporary challenges, advocating for a relational understanding of justification. JÃ¼ngel's work has been influential in ecumenical dialogues, particularly between Lutheran and Reformed traditions, and he remains a pivotal figure in discussions on the nature of God, revelation, and human existence.

timeline.event: Completed doctoral studies under Karl Barth at the University of Basel
Published 'God as the Mystery of the World'
Appointed Professor of Systematic Theology at the University of TÃ¼bingen

themes.label: Dialectical Theology
themes.gloss: JÃ¼ngel's theology is deeply rooted in the dialectical method, influenced by Karl Barth, emphasizing the paradoxical nature of divine revelation and the human response. He argues that God's self-revelation is both concealed and revealed, maintaining a tension that preserves the mystery of the divine.

themes.label: Trinitarian Theology
themes.gloss: In 'The Doctrine of the Trinity: God's Being is in Becoming,' JÃ¼ngel explores the dynamic nature of the Trinity, positing that God's being is constituted in relational self-giving love. This approach challenges static conceptions of God, emphasizing the active, relational nature of divine life.

themes.label: Justification
themes.gloss: JÃ¼ngel reinterprets the Lutheran doctrine of justification, advocating for a relational understanding that emphasizes God's act of justifying humanity through Christ. He critiques traditional forensic models, proposing a more dynamic, existential approach that aligns with contemporary theological concerns.

name: Gordon D. Fee
bio: Gordon D. Fee was a prominent Pentecostal theologian and New Testament scholar renowned for his rigorous exegetical work and contributions to biblical hermeneutics. Born in 1934, Fee's academic journey led him to become a leading voice in the Pentecostal-charismatic tradition. His scholarly work is marked by a commitment to the historical-critical method, which he adeptly applied to his studies of the Pauline epistles. Fee's most influential works include 'God's Empowering Presence' (1994) and 'Paul, the Spirit, and the People of God' (1996), where he explored the role of the Holy Spirit in the life of the early church, emphasizing the experiential and communal aspects of the Spirit's work. Fee engaged in dialogue with scholars such as F.F. Bruce and Richard Bauckham, contributing to debates on Pauline theology and pneumatology. His tenure at institutions like Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary and Regent College further solidified his influence in evangelical and Pentecostal circles. Fee's work was not without controversy; his egalitarian stance on gender roles in the church, articulated in 'Listening to the Spirit in the Text' (2000), challenged traditionalist views and sparked significant discussion. His exegetical precision and theological insights have left a lasting impact on contemporary biblical scholarship and the global Pentecostal movement.

timeline.event: Published 'The First Epistle to the Corinthians'
Published 'Paul, the Spirit, and the People of God'

themes.label: Pneumatology
themes.gloss: Fee's pneumatology is characterized by a robust emphasis on the experiential and communal dimensions of the Holy Spirit's work. He argues for the centrality of the Spirit in Pauline theology, advocating for a dynamic and participatory understanding of the Spirit's role in the life of the believer and the church.

themes.label: Pauline Theology
themes.gloss: Fee's contributions to Pauline theology focus on the integration of historical-critical methods with theological reflection. He emphasizes the continuity between Paul's Jewish heritage and his Christian proclamation, particularly in relation to the Spirit and eschatology.

themes.label: Egalitarianism
themes.gloss: Fee's egalitarian stance is evident in his interpretation of Pauline texts concerning gender roles. He argues for the equal participation of women in ministry, challenging traditionalist interpretations and advocating for a reading of Scripture that aligns with the liberating work of the Spirit.

name: Graeme Goldsworthy
bio: Graeme Goldsworthy is a prominent Australian theologian known for his contributions to biblical theology within the evangelical tradition. Born in 1934, Goldsworthy has been influential in developing a Christocentric hermeneutic, emphasizing the unity of Scripture through the lens of salvation history. His academic journey was significantly shaped by his education at Moore Theological College, where he later served as a lecturer. Goldsworthy's theological framework is deeply rooted in the Reformed tradition, drawing heavily on the works of Geerhardus Vos and Edmund Clowney, while also engaging with contemporary evangelical scholarship. His seminal works, such as 'Gospel and Kingdom' (1981), 'Gospel and Wisdom' (1987), and 'According to Plan' (1991), articulate a coherent narrative theology that underscores the centrality of Christ in both the Old and New Testaments. Goldsworthy's approach has been both lauded and critiqued for its insistence on a typological reading of Scripture, which some argue risks oversimplifying the diversity of biblical genres. Despite this, his influence is evident in the way many evangelicals approach biblical interpretation today. Goldsworthy's work has sparked dialogue and debate, particularly around the role of biblical theology in preaching and teaching, positioning him as a pivotal figure in contemporary evangelical thought.

themes.label: Christocentric Hermeneutic
themes.gloss: Goldsworthy emphasizes a Christ-centered approach to biblical interpretation, arguing that all Scripture points to Christ and should be understood through the lens of the gospel narrative. This approach seeks to maintain the unity of the Bible by focusing on the overarching theme of redemption.

themes.label: Biblical Theology
themes.gloss: Goldsworthy is a key proponent of biblical theology, which he defines as the study of the progressive unfolding of God's revelation in history. He argues for a canonical approach that sees the Bible as a unified narrative centered on God's redemptive work through Christ.

themes.label: Typology
themes.gloss: Goldsworthy employs typology as a hermeneutical tool, identifying patterns and foreshadowings of Christ in the Old Testament. He contends that typology is essential for understanding the continuity between the Testaments and the fulfillment of God's promises in Christ.

name: I. Howard Marshall
bio: I. Howard Marshall was a prominent British New Testament scholar and evangelical theologian, renowned for his rigorous exegesis and contributions to biblical hermeneutics. Born in 1934, Marshall's academic journey was primarily anchored at the University of Aberdeen, where he served as a professor of New Testament exegesis. His scholarly work was deeply influenced by the historical-critical method, yet he maintained a robust evangelical commitment, seeking to harmonize critical scholarship with faith. Marshall's interlocutors included notable figures such as F. F. Bruce and C. K. Barrett, with whom he shared a commitment to evangelical scholarship within the broader academic community. Among his significant contributions is his work on the theology of the New Testament, particularly his seminal book 'New Testament Theology: Many Witnesses, One Gospel' (2004), which articulated a cohesive theological narrative across diverse New Testament writings. Marshall was also involved in the translation of the New International Version (NIV) of the Bible, reflecting his commitment to making biblical texts accessible to contemporary audiences. His work often sparked discussions on the nature of biblical inspiration and authority, positioning him as a key figure in debates over the interface between critical scholarship and evangelical theology. Marshall's legacy is marked by his ability to engage critically with the text while affirming the central tenets of evangelical faith, leaving an indelible impact on both academic and ecclesial communities.

timeline.event: Published 'New Testament Theology: Many Witnesses, One Gospel'

themes.label: New Testament Theology
themes.gloss: Marshall's approach to New Testament theology emphasized the unity and diversity of the New Testament writings, advocating for a coherent theological narrative that respects the distinct voices of each text. His work sought to bridge the gap between historical-critical methods and evangelical convictions.

themes.label: Biblical Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Marshall contributed significantly to the field of biblical hermeneutics, advocating for a method that integrates historical-critical insights with theological reflection. He emphasized the importance of understanding the historical context of biblical texts while affirming their theological relevance for contemporary faith.

themes.label: Evangelical Scholarship
themes.gloss: As an evangelical scholar, Marshall was committed to engaging with critical scholarship without compromising evangelical beliefs. He sought to demonstrate that rigorous academic study of the Bible could coexist with a commitment to its divine inspiration and authority.

name: Richard Swinburne
bio: Richard Swinburne is a prominent British philosopher and theologian, renowned for his rigorous defense of theism through analytic philosophy. Born in 1934, Swinburne has significantly contributed to the philosophy of religion, particularly through his trilogy: 'The Coherence of Theism' (1977), 'The Existence of God' (1979), and 'Faith and Reason' (1981). His work is characterized by a systematic approach to theistic arguments, employing probabilistic reasoning to argue for the existence of God. Swinburne's interlocutors include notable philosophers such as Alvin Plantinga and J.L. Mackie, with whom he engaged in debates over the rationality of belief in God. Swinburne's use of Bayesian probability to support theism has been both influential and controversial, sparking discussions on the applicability of such methods to theological claims. His defense of theism extends to topics like the problem of evil, where he posits that the existence of evil is compatible with a benevolent deity, given the greater goods that may arise from such evils. Swinburne's contributions have been pivotal in contemporary philosophical theology, making him a central figure in debates on the rationality of religious belief.

timeline.event: Appointed Nolloth Professor of the Philosophy of the Christian Religion at the University of Oxford

themes.label: Theistic Arguments
themes.gloss: Swinburne employs a cumulative case approach, using Bayesian probability to argue that the existence of God is more probable than not, synthesizing cosmological, teleological, and moral arguments.

themes.label: Problem of Evil
themes.gloss: Swinburne addresses the problem of evil by suggesting that the existence of evil is necessary for the realization of greater goods, such as free will and moral development.

themes.label: Divine Attributes
themes.gloss: He explores the coherence of divine attributes, arguing for a consistent and logical understanding of omnipotence, omniscience, and perfect goodness within a theistic framework.

themes.label: Faith and Reason
themes.gloss: Swinburne defends the rationality of religious faith, positing that faith can be supported by evidence and is not contrary to reason, thus bridging the gap between belief and rational justification.

name: Robert Sokolowski
bio: Robert Sokolowski is a prominent American philosopher and theologian, renowned for his contributions to phenomenology and its intersection with Catholic theology. Born in 1934, Sokolowski has been a pivotal figure in articulating how phenomenological methods can illuminate theological concepts. He is particularly noted for his work on the philosophy of language and its implications for understanding the nature of God and religious experience. Sokolowski's seminal text, 'The God of Faith and Reason: Foundations of Christian Theology,' explores the relationship between faith and reason, arguing for a harmonious integration of the two within the Catholic intellectual tradition. His engagement with the works of Edmund Husserl and Thomas Aquinas has been instrumental in his development of a phenomenological approach to theology, which emphasizes the intentionality of consciousness and the role of perception in religious belief. Sokolowski has also been involved in dialogues concerning the nature of liturgical practice and its theological significance, contributing to contemporary debates on the role of tradition and modernity in Catholic worship. His academic career has been largely associated with the Catholic University of America, where he has influenced a generation of scholars through his teaching and writing.

timeline.event: Published 'The God of Faith and Reason: Foundations of Christian Theology.'
Published 'Christian Faith & Human Understanding: Studies on the Eucharist, Trinity, and the Human Person.'

themes.label: Phenomenology and Theology
themes.gloss: Sokolowski integrates phenomenological methods with theological inquiry, emphasizing the intentionality of consciousness and how it shapes religious experience. His approach seeks to bridge the gap between faith and reason, drawing on Husserlian phenomenology to elucidate theological concepts.

themes.label: Faith and Reason
themes.gloss: In 'The God of Faith and Reason,' Sokolowski argues for a synthesis of faith and reason, proposing that rational inquiry and religious belief are not mutually exclusive but rather complementary. He explores how philosophical reasoning can deepen theological understanding.

themes.label: Liturgical Theology
themes.gloss: Sokolowski examines the theological significance of liturgical practices, arguing that they are not merely ritualistic but deeply formative of Christian identity and belief. He emphasizes the role of tradition in shaping contemporary worship and its theological implications.

name: Sidney Greidanus
bio: Sidney Greidanus is a prominent figure in contemporary Reformed theology, known for his contributions to biblical hermeneutics and homiletics. Born in 1935 in the Netherlands and later emigrating to Canada, Greidanus has been influential in shaping the way preachers approach the Old Testament. His academic career includes significant tenures at Calvin Theological Seminary and The King's University, where he has been instrumental in developing a Christocentric approach to preaching. Greidanus's work often dialogues with the likes of Karl Barth and Edmund Clowney, emphasizing the necessity of seeing Christ as the focal point of all Scripture. His seminal work, 'Preaching Christ from the Old Testament,' published in 1999, argues against a purely historical-critical method, advocating instead for a redemptive-historical approach that sees the Old Testament as inherently pointing to Christ. This has sparked discussions and debates within Reformed circles about the balance between historical context and theological interpretation. Greidanus's contributions extend beyond academia into practical ministry, where his methodologies have been adopted by pastors seeking to enrich their preaching with a deeper theological foundation. His influence is seen in the way contemporary Reformed preachers engage with biblical texts, striving to maintain fidelity to the text while also drawing out its Christological implications.

timeline.event: Published 'Preaching Christ from the Old Testament'

themes.label: Christocentric Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Greidanus champions a Christocentric approach to biblical interpretation, particularly in the Old Testament, arguing that all Scripture ultimately points to Christ. This method challenges traditional historical-critical approaches by emphasizing theological continuity and redemptive history.

themes.label: Redemptive-Historical Preaching
themes.gloss: He advocates for a preaching style that situates biblical narratives within the overarching story of redemption, highlighting the progressive revelation of God's salvific plan culminating in Christ. This approach seeks to connect individual texts to the broader biblical narrative.

themes.label: Critique of Historical-Critical Method
themes.gloss: Greidanus critiques the historical-critical method for its tendency to fragment the biblical text and overlook its theological unity. He argues for a hermeneutic that respects historical context while prioritizing the text's theological message and Christological focus.

name: Richard B. Gaffin Jr.
bio: Richard B. Gaffin Jr. is a prominent Reformed theologian known for his contributions to biblical theology and his emphasis on the redemptive-historical approach to Scripture. Born in 1936, Gaffin has been a pivotal figure at Westminster Theological Seminary, where he has both studied and taught, influencing generations of students. His theological development is deeply rooted in the Reformed tradition, particularly drawing on the works of Geerhardus Vos and Herman Ridderbos. Gaffin's interlocutors include contemporary theologians such as N.T. Wright, with whom he has engaged in discussions regarding the New Perspective on Paul. Gaffin is best known for his work on the doctrine of union with Christ, which he sees as central to understanding the Apostle Paul's theology. His book, 'Resurrection and Redemption,' is a seminal work that explores the eschatological dimensions of Paul's thought, arguing that the resurrection is the linchpin of redemptive history. Gaffin has also been involved in controversies surrounding the Federal Vision, where he has critiqued its perceived deviations from traditional Reformed soteriology. His distinctive contributions include a robust defense of the inerrancy of Scripture and a nuanced understanding of the ordo salutis, particularly emphasizing the eschatological aspects of justification and sanctification. Gaffin's work continues to be influential in Reformed circles, shaping contemporary discussions on biblical theology and hermeneutics.

timeline.event: Completed Th.M. at Westminster Theological Seminary

themes.label: Union with Christ
themes.gloss: Gaffin emphasizes union with Christ as the central motif in Pauline theology, arguing that it undergirds the believer's justification, sanctification, and glorification. He contends that this union is both forensic and transformative, reflecting the eschatological reality of the believer's new life in Christ.

themes.label: Redemptive-Historical Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Influenced by Geerhardus Vos, Gaffin advocates for a redemptive-historical approach to Scripture, which sees the Bible as a unified narrative centered on Christ's redemptive work. This perspective challenges atomistic readings and emphasizes the unfolding of God's covenantal purposes throughout history.

themes.label: Eschatology and Resurrection
themes.gloss: In 'Resurrection and Redemption,' Gaffin argues that the resurrection of Christ is the pivotal event in redemptive history, inaugurating the eschatological age. He posits that the believer's resurrection is both a present reality and a future hope, integral to understanding Paul's soteriology.

name: Richard John Neuhaus
bio: Richard John Neuhaus was a prominent Catholic theologian and public intellectual whose work significantly shaped the discourse on religion and public life in the late 20th and early 21st centuries. Born in Canada and later becoming a naturalized American citizen, Neuhaus was initially ordained as a Lutheran pastor before converting to Catholicism in 1990. He was a pivotal figure in the ecumenical movement, engaging in dialogues with figures such as Stanley Hauerwas and George Weigel. Neuhaus founded the influential journal 'First Things' in 1990, which became a leading platform for discussing the intersection of faith and politics. His book 'The Naked Public Square' (1984) critiqued the exclusion of religious voices from public discourse, arguing for a robust role of religion in shaping moral and ethical norms in society. Neuhaus was a staunch advocate for the pro-life movement and often engaged in debates surrounding bioethics and social justice. His theological contributions are marked by a commitment to the public relevance of religious belief, emphasizing the necessity of faith-informed reasoning in public policy. Neuhaus's legacy is characterized by his ability to bridge denominational divides and his unwavering commitment to the idea that religious convictions should inform public life.

timeline.event: Died in New York City, USA

themes.label: Religion and Public Life
themes.gloss: Neuhaus argued for the essential role of religious discourse in public life, challenging secularist perspectives that sought to marginalize religious voices in political and ethical debates.

themes.label: Ecumenism
themes.gloss: Neuhaus was a key figure in promoting ecumenical dialogue, particularly between Protestant and Catholic traditions, emphasizing shared moral and theological commitments.

themes.label: Pro-Life Advocacy
themes.gloss: A vocal proponent of the pro-life movement, Neuhaus's theological writings often addressed the sanctity of life, critiquing abortion and euthanasia from a Catholic ethical standpoint.

name: Anthony C. Thiselton
bio: Anthony C. Thiselton was a prominent British theologian known for his extensive work in hermeneutics and New Testament studies. Born in 1937, Thiselton's academic journey was marked by a profound engagement with both philosophical and theological traditions, which he synthesized in his approach to biblical interpretation. His seminal work, 'The Two Horizons' (1980), revolutionized hermeneutical theory by integrating Gadamerian philosophical hermeneutics with theological exegesis, emphasizing the dialogical nature of understanding. Thiselton's interlocutors included Hans-Georg Gadamer, Paul Ricoeur, and JÃ¼rgen Moltmann, whose ideas he critically engaged to develop a robust framework for interpreting biblical texts. His contributions extended to the field of systematic theology, where he addressed the challenges of postmodernity and the role of doctrine in contemporary faith communities. Thiselton's work often sparked debate, particularly his insistence on the necessity of historical-critical methods alongside theological interpretation, which positioned him at the center of discussions on the authority and relevance of Scripture. His later works, such as 'The Hermeneutics of Doctrine' (2007), further explored the interplay between doctrine and interpretation, advocating for a dynamic and contextually aware theological discourse. Thiselton's legacy is characterized by his commitment to bridging the gap between academic theology and ecclesial practice, making him a pivotal figure in contemporary Anglican theology.

themes.label: Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Thiselton's approach to hermeneutics was deeply influenced by Gadamer and Ricoeur, emphasizing the fusion of horizons and the dialogical process of understanding. He argued for a hermeneutical model that respects both the historical context of the text and the contemporary context of the reader.

themes.label: Doctrine and Interpretation
themes.gloss: In 'The Hermeneutics of Doctrine', Thiselton explored how doctrinal formulations can be understood as dynamic interpretations that are responsive to changing contexts. He advocated for a hermeneutical approach that sees doctrine as a living tradition rather than static propositions.

themes.label: Philosophical Theology
themes.gloss: Thiselton engaged with philosophical theology by integrating insights from contemporary philosophy into theological discourse. He was particularly interested in how philosophical hermeneutics could inform and enrich theological method and understanding.

name: Clark Pinnock
bio: Clark Pinnock was a Canadian theologian whose work significantly influenced evangelical theology, particularly through his advocacy for open theism and a more inclusive understanding of salvation. Born in 1937, Pinnock's theological journey began with a strong commitment to classical evangelicalism, but he gradually embraced more progressive views. His early work, such as 'Set Forth Your Case' (1967), demonstrated his apologetic prowess. However, it was his later writings, including 'The Openness of God' (1994), that marked a pivotal shift in his theological stance. Pinnock engaged with interlocutors like John Sanders and Gregory Boyd, who were also proponents of open theism, a view that posits God's knowledge of the future as dynamic rather than exhaustive. This stance sparked significant controversy within evangelical circles, leading to debates over the nature of divine foreknowledge and human freedom. Pinnock also contributed to discussions on inclusivism, arguing for a broader understanding of salvation that extends beyond explicit Christian confession, as articulated in 'A Wideness in God's Mercy' (1992). His theological evolution was not without criticism, facing opposition from figures like Norman Geisler. Despite controversies, Pinnock's work remains influential, challenging evangelicals to reconsider traditional doctrines in light of contemporary issues.

themes.label: Open Theism
themes.gloss: Pinnock was a leading advocate of open theism, which posits that Godâ€™s knowledge of the future is not exhaustive, allowing for genuine human freedom. This view challenges classical theism's assertion of divine omniscience and immutability.

themes.label: Inclusivism
themes.gloss: Pinnock argued for an inclusivist understanding of salvation, suggesting that God's grace could extend beyond explicit Christian faith. This perspective was articulated in his work 'A Wideness in God's Mercy', advocating for a more expansive view of divine mercy.

themes.label: Evangelical Theology
themes.gloss: Throughout his career, Pinnock sought to reformulate evangelical theology to engage with contemporary issues. His work often challenged traditional evangelical positions, urging a re-examination of doctrines in light of modern philosophical and theological developments.

name: David F. Wright
bio: David F. Wright was a prominent British theologian and church historian, renowned for his contributions to the understanding of early Christianity and the Reformation. Born in 1937, Wright's academic career was primarily associated with the University of Edinburgh, where he served as a professor of Patristic and Reformed Christianity. His scholarly work was marked by a rigorous engagement with the writings of the Church Fathers, particularly Augustine, and a nuanced exploration of Reformation theology. Wright's interlocutors included figures such as Karl Barth and John Calvin, whose works he critically engaged with to elucidate the continuity and divergence within Reformed thought. His editorial work on the 'Dictionary of Scottish Church History & Theology' remains a significant resource for scholars. Wright was involved in several theological controversies, notably his defense of traditional Reformed positions against modern liberal interpretations. His distinctive contributions include a robust defense of infant baptism, articulated in his numerous essays and lectures, where he argued for its historical and theological validity within the Reformed tradition. Wright's scholarship was characterized by a commitment to historical-critical methods, combined with a deep respect for the theological heritage of the church.

timeline.event: Published 'Dictionary of Scottish Church History & Theology'

themes.label: Infant Baptism
themes.gloss: Wright defended the practice of infant baptism within the Reformed tradition, arguing for its theological and historical continuity from the early church to the Reformation.

themes.label: Reformation (1500 - 1599) Theology
themes.gloss: He explored the nuances of Reformation theology, particularly engaging with Calvin's works to highlight the distinctiveness of Reformed thought.

themes.label: Patristic (100 - 749) Studies
themes.gloss: Wright's work in patristics focused on the writings of Augustine, providing critical insights into early Christian doctrines and their development.

name: Fleming Rutledge
bio: Fleming Rutledge is a prominent American Episcopal priest and theologian known for her incisive engagement with contemporary culture and her robust theological writings. Born in 1937, Rutledge was one of the first women to be ordained to the priesthood of the Episcopal Church in 1977. Her theological work is deeply rooted in the Anglican tradition, yet it engages broadly with Reformed and Lutheran thought. Rutledge's magnum opus, 'The Crucifixion: Understanding the Death of Jesus Christ' (2015), is a comprehensive exploration of the atonement, emphasizing the cosmic scope of Christ's victory over sin and death. She draws heavily on the works of Karl Barth and JÃ¼rgen Moltmann, while also engaging with patristic sources such as Athanasius. Rutledge is known for her critique of modern secularism and her insistence on the apocalyptic nature of the Gospel, which she argues is often neglected in contemporary theology. Her sermons and writings frequently address the intersection of faith and public life, challenging both the church and society to confront issues of justice and righteousness. Rutledge's theological contributions are marked by a commitment to the narrative of Scripture as the lens through which the church must understand its mission in the world.

timeline.event: Ordained as one of the first female Episcopal priests
Published 'The Crucifixion: Understanding the Death of Jesus Christ'

themes.label: Apocalyptic Theology
themes.gloss: Rutledge emphasizes the apocalyptic dimension of the Gospel, arguing that the in-breaking of God's kingdom through Christ is a transformative event that redefines history and human existence. She critiques the domestication of Christian eschatology and insists on the radical nature of God's intervention in the world.

themes.label: Atonement
themes.gloss: In 'The Crucifixion,' Rutledge explores the multifaceted nature of atonement, focusing on the Christus Victor motif. She argues that the cross is not merely a symbol of personal salvation but a cosmic event that defeats the powers of sin and death, drawing on patristic and Reformed sources.

themes.label: Scriptural Narrative
themes.gloss: Rutledge advocates for a narrative approach to Scripture, viewing the biblical story as the primary framework for understanding Christian doctrine and ethics. She challenges modern tendencies to fragment the biblical text, urging a holistic reading that emphasizes the unity of God's redemptive work.

name: Henri Blocher
bio: Henri Blocher is a prominent French evangelical theologian known for his contributions to systematic theology and his engagement with contemporary theological issues. Born in 1937, Blocher has been a significant figure in the evangelical tradition, particularly within the French-speaking world. He served as a professor of systematic theology at the FacultÃ© Libre de ThÃ©ologie Ã‰vangÃ©lique in Vaux-sur-Seine, France, and has been a visiting professor at Wheaton College in the United States. Blocher's theological work is characterized by a commitment to the authority of Scripture, a nuanced understanding of the doctrine of creation, and a robust engagement with contemporary philosophical and theological currents. His interlocutors include Karl Barth, with whom he shares a dialectical approach, and Wolfhart Pannenberg, whose emphasis on history and eschatology resonates with Blocher's own theological concerns. Blocher has been involved in various theological controversies, particularly those surrounding the interpretation of Genesis and the doctrine of original sin. His book 'In the Beginning' offers a critical yet constructive approach to the creation narratives, advocating for a historical Adam while engaging with scientific insights. Blocher's distinctive contributions lie in his ability to bridge the gap between traditional evangelical convictions and contemporary theological discourse, making him a pivotal figure in modern evangelical thought.

timeline.event: Joined FacultÃ© Libre de ThÃ©ologie Ã‰vangÃ©lique

themes.label: Doctrine of Creation
themes.gloss: Blocher emphasizes a historical reading of Genesis, advocating for a historical Adam while engaging with scientific insights. His work seeks to harmonize biblical exegesis with contemporary scientific understanding.

themes.label: Original Sin
themes.gloss: Blocher's treatment of original sin is marked by a commitment to its historical and theological significance, engaging with Augustinian and Reformed perspectives while addressing modern critiques.

themes.label: Authority of Scripture
themes.gloss: Blocher upholds the authority of Scripture as central to evangelical theology, advocating for a hermeneutic that respects the text's historical and literary contexts while affirming its divine inspiration.

name: O. Palmer Robertson
bio: O. Palmer Robertson is a prominent Reformed theologian known for his contributions to biblical theology and covenant theology. Born in 1937, Robertson has been influential in the Reformed tradition, particularly through his work on the structure and unity of the biblical covenants. He studied under John Murray at Westminster Theological Seminary, which significantly shaped his theological outlook. Robertson's seminal work, 'The Christ of the Covenants' (1980), argues for a unified covenantal framework that spans both the Old and New Testaments, emphasizing the continuity of God's redemptive plan. His approach counters dispensationalist readings, advocating instead for a cohesive narrative centered on Christ. Robertson has also engaged with the broader evangelical community, contributing to discussions on biblical inerrancy and hermeneutics. His tenure at Knox Theological Seminary and his founding role at African Bible University in Uganda highlight his commitment to theological education and global mission. Despite some controversies surrounding his staunch Reformed positions, Robertson remains a respected voice in contemporary theology, particularly among those who uphold the Westminster Confession of Faith.

timeline.event: Founded African Bible University in Uganda

themes.label: Covenant Theology
themes.gloss: Robertson's work emphasizes the unity and continuity of the biblical covenants, arguing against dispensationalist interpretations and advocating for a Christ-centered covenantal framework.

themes.label: Biblical Theology
themes.gloss: He is known for his contributions to biblical theology, focusing on the overarching narrative of Scripture and its theological coherence.

themes.label: Reformed Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Robertson upholds a Reformed hermeneutical approach, emphasizing the historical-grammatical method and the importance of biblical inerrancy.

name: David F. Wells
bio: David F. Wells is a prominent contemporary evangelical theologian known for his critical engagement with modernity and its impact on the church. Born in 1939, Wells has been a significant voice in critiquing the accommodation of evangelicalism to cultural trends, particularly through his series of books beginning with 'No Place for Truth' (1993). His theological development is marked by a robust defense of classical Reformed orthodoxy, emphasizing the transcendence of God and the authority of Scripture. Wells has engaged with interlocutors such as Carl F. H. Henry and J. I. Packer, sharing concerns about the dilution of doctrinal integrity in modern evangelicalism. His works often critique the consumerist and therapeutic tendencies within the church, arguing for a return to a theologically grounded faith. Controversially, Wells has been critical of the church growth movement and its pragmatic approaches, which he sees as compromising theological depth. His distinctive contributions include a call for a renewed understanding of the holiness of God and the centrality of doctrine in the life of the church. Wells's influence extends through his teaching roles at institutions like Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary, where he has shaped a generation of pastors and theologians.

themes.label: Critique of Modernity
themes.gloss: Wells critiques the influence of modernity on evangelicalism, arguing that cultural accommodation has led to a loss of doctrinal integrity and a diminished understanding of God's transcendence.

themes.label: Theology of Holiness
themes.gloss: Wells emphasizes the holiness of God as central to Christian theology, advocating for a return to a God-centered faith that resists the anthropocentric tendencies of contemporary culture.

themes.label: Authority of Scripture
themes.gloss: Wells defends the authority of Scripture against modern skepticism, arguing for its central role in shaping Christian belief and practice amidst cultural shifts.

name: Hans Schwarz
bio: Hans Schwarz is a prominent contemporary Lutheran theologian known for his contributions to systematic theology and his engagement with modern scientific discourse. Born in 1939 in Germany, Schwarz has been a pivotal figure in bridging the gap between faith and reason, particularly through his work on the dialogue between theology and science. He has served as a professor at the University of Regensburg, where he has influenced a generation of theologians with his interdisciplinary approach. Schwarz's theological development is marked by his engagement with existential questions and his commitment to a Christocentric theology that remains relevant in the modern world. His interlocutors include notable theologians such as Wolfhart Pannenberg and JÃ¼rgen Moltmann, with whom he shares a commitment to addressing contemporary issues through a theological lens. Schwarz has been involved in various controversies, particularly regarding the role of science in theological discourse, advocating for a constructive dialogue rather than a confrontational stance. His distinctive contributions include a robust theology of creation that emphasizes the interconnectedness of all creation and a soteriology that underscores the universal scope of Christ's salvific work. Schwarz's works, such as 'Theology in a Global Context' and 'Creation,' reflect his commitment to a theology that is both academically rigorous and pastorally sensitive.

timeline.event: Appointed professor at the University of Regensburg

themes.label: Theology and Science
themes.gloss: Schwarz advocates for a harmonious relationship between theology and science, arguing that both disciplines can enrich each other. He challenges the notion of conflict between faith and reason, proposing instead a dialogue that respects the integrity of both fields.

themes.label: Christocentric Theology
themes.gloss: Central to Schwarz's theology is a focus on Christ as the revelation of God. He emphasizes the importance of Christology in understanding the nature of God and the purpose of creation, arguing for a theology that is rooted in the life and teachings of Jesus Christ.

themes.label: Creation Theology
themes.gloss: Schwarz's theology of creation highlights the interconnectedness of all life and the responsibility of humanity to care for the environment. He integrates ecological concerns into his theological framework, advocating for a stewardship model that respects the integrity of creation.

name: James D.G. Dunn
bio: James D.G. Dunn was a prominent British New Testament scholar known for his influential work on the New Perspective on Paul. Born in 1939, Dunn's academic career was primarily associated with the University of Durham, where he served as Lightfoot Professor of Divinity. His theological development was deeply rooted in historical-critical methods, and he engaged extensively with the works of E.P. Sanders and N.T. Wright. Dunn's seminal contribution to Pauline studies was his re-evaluation of first-century Judaism and its implications for understanding Paul's writings, particularly in relation to the doctrine of justification. This perspective challenged traditional Protestant interpretations and sparked significant debate among scholars. Dunn's major works include 'The Theology of Paul the Apostle' (1998) and 'Jesus Remembered' (2003), the first volume of his trilogy 'Christianity in the Making'. His scholarship emphasized the continuity between Jesus and early Christianity, arguing against the notion of a radical break. Dunn was also known for his work on the Holy Spirit, advocating for a more dynamic understanding of pneumatology within the early Christian communities. His contributions to the field of New Testament studies have left a lasting impact, fostering ongoing dialogue and reassessment of key theological concepts.

timeline.event: Completed PhD at the University of Cambridge
Published 'The Theology of Paul the Apostle'

themes.label: New Perspective on Paul
themes.gloss: Dunn's work redefined the understanding of Paul's writings by emphasizing the Jewish context of first-century Christianity. He argued that Paul's doctrine of justification should be seen as a critique of Jewish exclusivism rather than a polemic against legalism, thus reshaping Pauline theology.

themes.label: Historical Jesus
themes.gloss: In 'Jesus Remembered', Dunn focused on the continuity between the historical Jesus and the early Christian movement. He argued against the notion of a radical discontinuity, emphasizing the importance of oral tradition in preserving the teachings of Jesus.

themes.label: Pneumatology
themes.gloss: Dunn's exploration of the Holy Spirit highlighted its role in the life of early Christian communities. He advocated for a dynamic and experiential understanding of pneumatology, emphasizing the Spirit's transformative power in believers' lives.

name: John F. MacArthur
bio: John F. MacArthur is a prominent American evangelical pastor, theologian, and author, renowned for his expository preaching and staunch defense of biblical inerrancy. Born in 1939, MacArthur has served as the pastor-teacher of Grace Community Church in Sun Valley, California, since 1969. He is the president of The Master's University and Seminary, where he has influenced a generation of pastors and theologians. MacArthur's theological development is deeply rooted in Reformed theology, though he is distinctively dispensational in his eschatology. His interlocutors include figures such as R.C. Sproul and J.I. Packer, with whom he shares a commitment to Reformed soteriology, yet diverges on covenant theology. MacArthur has been a central figure in several controversies, notably the 'Lordship Salvation' debate, where he argued against the notion of easy-believism, insisting that genuine faith must produce obedience. His works, such as 'The Gospel According to Jesus' (1988), have been pivotal in this discourse. MacArthur's contributions extend to his critique of the charismatic movement, articulated in 'Charismatic Chaos' (1992), and his defense of cessationism. His commitment to biblical authority and expository preaching has left an indelible mark on evangelicalism, making him a key figure in contemporary theological discourse.

timeline.event: Became pastor-teacher at Grace Community Church

themes.label: Lordship Salvation
themes.gloss: MacArthur's 'Lordship Salvation' theology asserts that true faith in Christ inherently involves submission to His lordship, countering the 'easy-believism' prevalent in some evangelical circles. His seminal work, 'The Gospel According to Jesus,' challenges the notion that one can accept Jesus as Savior without acknowledging Him as Lord.

themes.label: Biblical Inerrancy
themes.gloss: MacArthur is a staunch advocate for the inerrancy of Scripture, holding that the Bible is without error in all its teachings. His commitment to this doctrine is evident in his expository preaching and his role in the International Council on Biblical Inerrancy.

themes.label: Cessationism
themes.gloss: In 'Charismatic Chaos,' MacArthur argues for cessationism, the belief that the miraculous gifts of the Spirit, such as speaking in tongues and prophecy, ceased with the apostolic age. He critiques the charismatic movement for its perceived deviations from biblical orthodoxy.

name: John M. Frame
bio: John M. Frame is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian known for his contributions to epistemology, apologetics, and systematic theology. Born in 1939, Frame has been a pivotal figure in the development of a distinctly Reformed approach to theology that integrates philosophy and biblical exegesis. He studied under Cornelius Van Til, whose presuppositional apologetics significantly influenced Frame's own work. Frame's theological development is marked by his emphasis on the lordship of Christ over all areas of life, a theme he explores extensively in his multi-volume work, 'The Theology of Lordship.' His interlocutors include figures like Richard B. Gaffin and Vern Poythress, with whom he shares a commitment to the authority of Scripture. Frame has been involved in controversies surrounding the nature of God's sovereignty and human responsibility, often engaging with open theism and process theology. His distinctive contributions include a triperspectival approach to theology, which posits that theological issues can be understood from normative, situational, and existential perspectives. This framework has been influential in Reformed circles, offering a nuanced method for theological reflection. Frame's works, such as 'The Doctrine of the Knowledge of God' and 'Apologetics to the Glory of God,' continue to be foundational texts in Reformed theological education.

timeline.event: Published 'The Doctrine of the Knowledge of God'

themes.label: Triperspectivalism
themes.gloss: Frame's triperspectivalism offers a methodological approach to theology that considers normative, situational, and existential perspectives, providing a comprehensive framework for understanding theological issues.

themes.label: Presuppositional Apologetics
themes.gloss: Influenced by Cornelius Van Til, Frame advances presuppositional apologetics, arguing that all reasoning is based on presuppositions and that Christian faith provides the only coherent foundation for rational thought.

themes.label: Lordship of Christ
themes.gloss: Frame emphasizes the lordship of Christ over all aspects of life, arguing that theology must reflect Christ's sovereign rule, which he elaborates in his 'Theology of Lordship' series.

name: R.C. Sproul
bio: R.C. Sproul was a prominent American theologian known for his rigorous defense of Reformed theology and his influential role in the resurgence of Calvinism in the late 20th century. Born in 1939, Sproul's theological journey was deeply shaped by his studies at Westminster College, Pittsburgh Theological Seminary, and the Free University of Amsterdam. He founded Ligonier Ministries in 1971, which became a pivotal platform for disseminating Reformed theology through teaching series, books, and conferences. Sproul's interlocutors included figures like John Gerstner, who mentored him in Reformed thought, and contemporaries such as John MacArthur and J.I. Packer, with whom he shared a commitment to biblical inerrancy. A central controversy in Sproul's career was his staunch opposition to the Roman Catholic Church's doctrines, particularly during the Evangelicals and Catholics Together initiative, where he argued vehemently for the doctrinal purity of the Reformation principles. His distinctive contributions include a robust articulation of the doctrine of justification by faith alone and a defense of the classical doctrine of God, as seen in his seminal work, 'The Holiness of God'. Sproul's legacy is marked by his ability to communicate complex theological concepts to lay audiences, making him a pivotal figure in contemporary Reformed circles.

themes.label: Justification by Faith Alone
themes.gloss: Sproul ardently defended the Reformation doctrine of sola fide, emphasizing its centrality to the gospel and critiquing any theological stance that compromised this principle.

themes.label: The Holiness of God
themes.gloss: In his influential work, Sproul expounded on the transcendence and majesty of God's holiness, arguing that a proper understanding of God's nature is foundational to Christian theology.

themes.label: Biblical Inerrancy
themes.gloss: Sproul was a key figure in the International Council on Biblical Inerrancy, advocating for the complete trustworthiness and authority of Scripture against modern critical approaches.

name: Robert Benne
bio: Robert Benne is a prominent American Lutheran theologian known for his contributions to the dialogue between faith and public life. Born in 1939, Benne has been a significant voice in contemporary Lutheran thought, particularly in the context of ethics and social issues. He served as a professor and director of the Center for Religion and Society at Roanoke College, where he influenced many through his teachings and writings. Benne's theological development is marked by his engagement with Lutheran confessionalism and its implications for modern ethical dilemmas. His interlocutors include figures like Richard John Neuhaus and Stanley Hauerwas, with whom he shares a commitment to the public role of religion. Benne has been involved in controversies surrounding the role of Christianity in public policy, often advocating for a robust presence of Christian ethics in the public square. His distinctive contributions include a nuanced understanding of the two kingdoms doctrine, which he applies to contemporary socio-political contexts, arguing for a balance between church and state responsibilities. His works, such as 'Quality with Soul' and 'Good and Bad Ways to Think about Religion and Politics,' reflect his commitment to integrating faith with public life, emphasizing the importance of moral and ethical considerations in societal governance.

themes.label: Two Kingdoms Doctrine
themes.gloss: Benne's interpretation of the two kingdoms doctrine emphasizes a dynamic interaction between the spiritual and temporal realms. He argues for a balanced approach where the church influences public policy without overstepping its bounds, advocating for ethical engagement in societal issues.

themes.label: Faith and Public Life
themes.gloss: Benne stresses the importance of Christian ethics in public discourse. He believes that faith should inform public life, advocating for a moral framework that guides political and social decisions, while respecting pluralism and democratic principles.

themes.label: Lutheran Confessionalism
themes.gloss: Benne's work is deeply rooted in Lutheran confessionalism, which he applies to contemporary ethical issues. He emphasizes the relevance of Lutheran teachings in addressing modern challenges, advocating for a confessional approach that is both faithful and adaptable.

name: Donald Macleod
bio: Donald Macleod is a prominent Scottish theologian known for his contributions to Reformed theology and his tenure as Principal of the Free Church of Scotland College. Born in 1940, Macleod has been a significant voice in contemporary theological discourse, particularly within the Reformed tradition. His theological development was influenced by his education at the University of Edinburgh and his subsequent academic career. Macleod's work often engages with classical Reformed doctrines, yet he is also known for addressing modern theological challenges. He has been involved in various controversies, notably his defense of the Free Church's traditional positions against liberalizing trends. Macleod's interlocutors include figures like Karl Barth and John Calvin, whose works he critically engages with to articulate a robust Reformed theology that is both historically grounded and responsive to contemporary issues. His distinctive contributions include a strong emphasis on the sovereignty of God, the authority of Scripture, and the necessity of Christ's atonement. Macleod's writings, such as 'The Person of Christ' and 'A Faith to Live By', reflect his commitment to a theology that is both intellectually rigorous and pastorally relevant.

timeline.event: Appointed Principal of Free Church of Scotland College
Retired from Free Church of Scotland College

themes.label: Sovereignty of God
themes.gloss: Macleod emphasizes the absolute sovereignty of God as central to Reformed theology, arguing that it underpins the doctrines of grace and providence. He contends that God's sovereignty is not only a theological axiom but also a pastoral comfort.

themes.label: Authority of Scripture
themes.gloss: Macleod staunchly defends the inerrancy and authority of Scripture, positioning it as the ultimate norm for faith and practice. He critiques modern theological trends that undermine biblical authority, advocating for a return to a high view of Scripture.

themes.label: Christology
themes.gloss: In his Christological work, Macleod explores the person and work of Christ with a focus on the hypostatic union and the atonement. He engages with historical and contemporary debates, affirming the necessity and sufficiency of Christ's redemptive work.

name: Kevin Giles
bio: Kevin Giles is an Australian theologian known for his extensive work on the doctrine of the Trinity and gender relations within the church. Born in 1940, Giles has been a prominent voice in contemporary evangelical theology, particularly in debates surrounding the eternal subordination of the Son. His theological development was significantly influenced by his studies at Moore Theological College and later at the University of Durham, where he engaged deeply with patristic sources. Giles has been a vocal critic of the complementarian view that posits a hierarchical relationship within the Trinity, arguing instead for an egalitarian perspective that emphasizes the co-equality of the divine persons. His interlocutors include theologians such as Wayne Grudem and Bruce Ware, with whom he has engaged in rigorous debate over the implications of Trinitarian doctrine for gender roles. Giles's notable works include 'The Trinity and Subordinationism' (2002) and 'Jesus and the Father: Modern Evangelicals Reinvent the Doctrine of the Trinity' (2006), where he critiques the misuse of Trinitarian theology to support gender hierarchy. His contributions have been pivotal in shaping contemporary evangelical discourse on both the Trinity and gender, advocating for a return to Nicene orthodoxy and a more inclusive understanding of gender roles in the church.

themes.label: Trinitarian Theology
themes.gloss: Giles challenges the eternal subordination of the Son, advocating for a co-equal Trinity, aligning with Nicene orthodoxy against contemporary hierarchical interpretations.

themes.label: Gender and Theology
themes.gloss: Giles argues against complementarianism, promoting egalitarianism in church leadership and gender roles, emphasizing biblical equality.

themes.label: Patristic (100 - 749) Engagement
themes.gloss: Giles draws on patristic sources to critique modern evangelical interpretations of the Trinity, advocating for a return to early church understandings.

name: Paul Helm
bio: Paul Helm is a prominent British theologian and philosopher known for his contributions to Reformed theology and philosophical theology. Born in 1940, Helm has been influential in the discourse on divine foreknowledge, providence, and the nature of God. His academic career includes positions at the University of Liverpool and King's College London, where he has engaged deeply with the works of John Calvin and Jonathan Edwards. Helm's theological development is marked by a robust defense of classical theism, particularly in the context of contemporary philosophical challenges. He has been a critical interlocutor with open theism, arguing for the coherence and necessity of divine timelessness and immutability. His book 'Eternal God: A Study of God without Time' (1988) is a seminal work that defends the timelessness of God against modern critiques. Helm has also contributed significantly to the understanding of Calvinist epistemology, emphasizing the role of divine revelation and the sensus divinitatis. His engagement with the problem of evil is characterized by a commitment to the Augustinian tradition, asserting that evil is a privation of good rather than a substantive entity. Helm's work continues to influence contemporary debates on the nature of divine attributes and the intersection of faith and reason.

timeline.event: Published 'Eternal God: A Study of God without Time'
Appointed Professor of the History and Philosophy of Religion at King's College London

themes.label: Divine Timelessness
themes.gloss: Helm argues for the timeless nature of God, positing that God exists outside of time and is immutable. He critiques the view that divine temporality is necessary for genuine interaction with creation, maintaining that timelessness is essential for God's sovereignty and omniscience.

themes.label: Providence and Foreknowledge
themes.gloss: Helm defends a Reformed understanding of divine providence, emphasizing God's meticulous governance of creation. He argues that divine foreknowledge is compatible with human freedom, rejecting open theism's claims that God's knowledge is limited to actualized events.

themes.label: Calvinist Epistemology
themes.gloss: Helm explores the epistemological implications of Calvinism, particularly the role of the sensus divinitatis and the noetic effects of sin. He argues that true knowledge of God is dependent on divine revelation and the regenerative work of the Holy Spirit.

name: Richard J. Mouw
bio: Richard J. Mouw is a prominent American theologian known for his contributions to Reformed theology and his engagement with contemporary cultural issues. Born in 1940, Mouw has been a significant voice in the dialogue between evangelical Christianity and broader societal concerns. He served as the President of Fuller Theological Seminary from 1993 to 2013, where he emphasized the importance of civility in public discourse and interfaith dialogue. Mouw's theological development is deeply rooted in the Reformed tradition, yet he is noted for his openness to engaging with diverse theological perspectives, including those of Roman Catholicism and Judaism. His interlocutors include theologians such as Abraham Kuyper, whose neo-Calvinist ideas have influenced Mouw's thought, particularly in the realm of public theology. Mouw has been involved in controversies surrounding the role of evangelicalism in American politics, advocating for a more nuanced and less partisan approach. His distinctive contributions include a robust defense of common grace and the cultural mandate, arguing for the Christian's responsibility to engage constructively with the world. Mouw's works, such as 'Uncommon Decency: Christian Civility in an Uncivil World,' reflect his commitment to fostering dialogue and understanding across ideological divides.

timeline.event: Became President of Fuller Theological Seminary
Retired as President of Fuller Theological Seminary
Published 'Uncommon Decency: Christian Civility in an Uncivil World'

themes.label: Common Grace
themes.gloss: Mouw emphasizes the doctrine of common grace, advocating that God's grace extends to all of creation, allowing for positive cultural engagement and collaboration with non-Christians.

themes.label: Public Theology
themes.gloss: Mouw argues for a public theology that is deeply rooted in Reformed principles yet actively engages with contemporary societal issues, promoting a balanced approach to political and cultural involvement.

themes.label: Interfaith Dialogue
themes.gloss: Mouw is a proponent of respectful and meaningful dialogue between different faith traditions, particularly focusing on fostering understanding and cooperation between evangelicals and other religious communities.

name: Stanley Hauerwas
bio: Stanley Hauerwas is a prominent American theologian known for his work in Christian ethics and the role of the church in society. Born in 1940, Hauerwas has been a significant voice in contemporary theological discourse, particularly within the Methodist-Wesleyan tradition. His theological development is marked by a strong emphasis on narrative theology and virtue ethics, drawing heavily from the works of Alasdair MacIntyre and John Howard Yoder. Hauerwas's interlocutors include figures such as Karl Barth, whose ecclesiology influenced his thought, and Reinhold Niebuhr, whose Christian realism he often critiques. A controversial figure, Hauerwas challenges the liberal Protestant accommodation to modernity, advocating instead for a robust ecclesial community that resists secularization. His distinctive contributions include a critique of American civil religion and the advocacy of pacifism as a core Christian practice. Hauerwas's seminal works, such as 'A Community of Character' (1981) and 'Resident Aliens' (1989, co-authored with William Willimon), argue for the church as an alternative polis, embodying a counter-cultural narrative. His tenure at Duke University solidified his influence, where he engaged in rigorous debates on the nature of Christian ethics and the church's role in public life.

timeline.event: Named 'America's Best Theologian' by Time magazine

themes.label: Narrative Theology
themes.gloss: Hauerwas emphasizes the importance of narrative in shaping Christian ethics, arguing that the church's story provides a framework for moral formation distinct from secular narratives.

themes.label: Virtue Ethics
themes.gloss: Influenced by Alasdair MacIntyre, Hauerwas advocates for a virtue-based ethical system, where character and community are central to moral decision-making, contrasting with rule-based ethics.

themes.label: Pacifism
themes.gloss: Hauerwas is a staunch advocate of Christian pacifism, viewing it as an essential witness of the church against the violence inherent in state power and civil religion.

name: J. Denny Weaver
bio: J. Denny Weaver is a prominent contemporary Anabaptist theologian known for his contributions to peace theology and nonviolent atonement theory. Born in 1941, Weaver has been a significant voice in reinterpreting traditional Christian doctrines through an Anabaptist lens. His seminal work, 'The Nonviolent Atonement' (2001), challenges the prevailing satisfaction and penal substitution models of atonement by proposing a narrative Christus Victor model that emphasizes Jesus' life and teachings as a paradigm of nonviolent resistance. Weaver's theological development is deeply rooted in the Anabaptist tradition, drawing from historical figures such as Menno Simons and engaging with contemporary theologians like Stanley Hauerwas and John Howard Yoder. Weaver's work has sparked considerable debate, particularly among those who adhere to more traditional atonement theories. His approach is characterized by a commitment to peace and justice, advocating for a theology that aligns with the ethical teachings of Jesus. Weaver's contributions extend beyond academic circles, influencing church practices and discussions on social justice. His work continues to inspire a reimagining of Christian theology that is both faithful to the Anabaptist tradition and responsive to contemporary ethical challenges.

timeline.event: Revised edition of 'The Nonviolent Atonement' released
Continues to influence Anabaptist theology and peace studies

themes.label: Nonviolent Atonement
themes.gloss: Weaver's nonviolent atonement theory critiques traditional models like penal substitution, proposing instead a narrative Christus Victor model that emphasizes Jesus' life and teachings as a paradigm of nonviolent resistance.

themes.label: Peace Theology
themes.gloss: Weaver's work is deeply rooted in Anabaptist peace theology, advocating for a Christian ethic that prioritizes nonviolence and social justice, drawing from the teachings of Jesus and historical Anabaptist figures.

themes.label: Narrative Theology
themes.gloss: Weaver employs narrative theology to reinterpret Christian doctrines, focusing on the life and teachings of Jesus as central to understanding theological concepts, particularly in the context of atonement and ethics.

name: John D. Woodbridge
bio: John D. Woodbridge is a distinguished evangelical historian and theologian, renowned for his contributions to the understanding of church history and historical theology. Born in 1941, Woodbridge has been a pivotal figure in contemporary evangelical scholarship, particularly through his tenure at Trinity Evangelical Divinity School. His work often intersects with the historical-critical method, yet he maintains a robust evangelical framework, engaging critically with both secular and religious historiography. Woodbridge's scholarship is marked by a commitment to historical accuracy and a defense of orthodox Christian doctrines against modernist critiques. He has been a vocal interlocutor in debates surrounding biblical inerrancy, contributing significantly to the Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy in 1978. His works, such as 'Biblical Authority: A Critique of the Rogers/McKim Proposal,' have addressed the challenges posed by liberal theological perspectives, advocating for a return to traditional evangelical understandings of scripture. Woodbridge's engagement with figures like Carl F. H. Henry and Harold Lindsell has further solidified his role as a defender of evangelical orthodoxy. His scholarly rigor and commitment to the historical faith have made him a respected voice in both academic and ecclesiastical circles.

timeline.event: Joined faculty at Trinity Evangelical Divinity School
Contributed to the Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy
Published 'Biblical Authority: A Critique of the Rogers/McKim Proposal'

themes.label: Biblical Inerrancy
themes.gloss: Woodbridge has been a staunch advocate for the doctrine of biblical inerrancy, arguing against modernist interpretations that undermine scriptural authority. His involvement in the Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy underscores his commitment to this theological stance.

themes.label: Historical Theology
themes.gloss: Woodbridge's approach to historical theology emphasizes the importance of historical context in understanding doctrinal development, while maintaining a commitment to evangelical orthodoxy.

themes.label: Evangelical Historiography
themes.gloss: He has contributed to the field of evangelical historiography by critiquing secular historical methods and advocating for a historiography that respects both historical rigor and theological commitments.

name: Robert Kolb
bio: Robert Kolb is a prominent contemporary Lutheran theologian known for his extensive work on Reformation history and theology, particularly focusing on Martin Luther and the Lutheran Confessions. Born in 1941, Kolb has been a pivotal figure in Lutheran scholarship, serving as a professor at Concordia Seminary in St. Louis. His scholarly pursuits have centered on elucidating the theological and historical contexts of the Reformation, with a particular emphasis on the dynamics of law and gospel, the role of the catechisms, and the development of Lutheran identity. Kolb has engaged in dialogue with various theological traditions, contributing to ecumenical discussions and fostering a deeper understanding of Lutheran doctrine in a global context. His notable works include 'The Christian Faith: A Lutheran Exposition' and 'Martin Luther: Confessor of the Faith,' which have been instrumental in shaping contemporary Lutheran thought. Kolb's contributions have not been without controversy, particularly in his interpretations of Luther's theology in relation to modern issues. His work often challenges traditional readings, advocating for a nuanced understanding of historical texts. Kolb's scholarship is marked by a commitment to historical-critical methodology, aiming to bridge the gap between historical context and contemporary application, thus making significant contributions to both academic and ecclesial communities.

timeline.event: Published 'The Christian Faith: A Lutheran Exposition'
Published 'Martin Luther: Confessor of the Faith'

themes.label: Law and Gospel
themes.gloss: Kolb emphasizes the dialectical relationship between law and gospel in Lutheran theology, arguing for their distinct yet complementary roles in the believer's life. He contends that understanding this dynamic is crucial for grasping Luther's theological framework.

themes.label: Lutheran Confessions
themes.gloss: Kolb's work on the Lutheran Confessions highlights their historical development and theological significance. He advocates for their continued relevance in contemporary Lutheran identity and practice, stressing their role in articulating core doctrinal positions.

themes.label: Catechetical Instruction
themes.gloss: Kolb underscores the importance of catechetical instruction in the Lutheran tradition, viewing it as a vital tool for doctrinal education and spiritual formation. He explores its historical roots and modern applications, advocating for its adaptation to contemporary contexts.

name: Al Wolters
bio: Al Wolters is a prominent Canadian theologian and philosopher, best known for his contributions to the neo-Calvinist tradition, particularly through his work on worldview and biblical hermeneutics. Born in 1942, Wolters has been a significant figure in the development of reformational thought, drawing heavily on the works of Abraham Kuyper and Herman Dooyeweerd. His seminal book, 'Creation Regained: Biblical Basics for a Reformational Worldview' (1985), has been influential in articulating a comprehensive Christian worldview that emphasizes the goodness of creation and the cultural mandate. Wolters' work engages deeply with the concept of 'structure and direction,' a framework that distinguishes between the inherent order of creation and the ways in which it can be directed either towards or away from God's intentions. His interlocutors include figures like Nicholas Wolterstorff and Richard Mouw, with whom he shares a commitment to integrating faith and learning. Wolters has also been involved in controversies surrounding the interpretation of Genesis, advocating for a non-literal reading that respects both the theological and scientific dimensions of the text. His contributions extend to the field of biblical studies, where he has applied reformational philosophy to hermeneutics, emphasizing the need for a holistic approach that considers historical, literary, and theological contexts. Wolters' work continues to inspire scholars and practitioners seeking to apply a reformational perspective to contemporary cultural and intellectual challenges.

themes.label: Worldview
themes.gloss: Wolters emphasizes a reformational worldview that integrates faith with all areas of life, advocating for a holistic approach that sees all of creation as inherently good and subject to God's redemptive purposes.

themes.label: Structure and Direction
themes.gloss: He distinguishes between the inherent structure of creation and the direction it takes, arguing that while creation is fundamentally good, it can be directed towards or away from God's intentions.

themes.label: Biblical Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Wolters applies reformational philosophy to biblical interpretation, advocating for a non-literal reading of Genesis that respects both theological insights and scientific understanding.

name: Bruce Reichenbach
bio: Bruce Reichenbach is a contemporary American philosopher and theologian known for his contributions to the philosophy of religion and ethics. Born in 1942, Reichenbach has been a prominent figure in philosophical theology, engaging deeply with issues surrounding the existence of God, the problem of evil, and the nature of faith. He has been particularly influential in discussions on the cosmological argument, where he has defended a version of the Kalam cosmological argument, emphasizing the necessity of a first cause. Reichenbach's work often intersects with that of William Lane Craig, with whom he shares a commitment to the rational defense of theism. His book 'Evil and a Good God' (1982) addresses theodicy, arguing for a free will defense that reconciles the existence of evil with a benevolent deity. Reichenbach has also engaged with the ethical implications of religious belief, exploring how moral frameworks can be grounded in theological contexts. His work is characterized by a rigorous analytical approach, often employing logical and philosophical tools to address theological questions. Reichenbach's contributions have sparked dialogue and debate, particularly among those interested in the intersection of philosophy and theology, and he remains a respected voice in contemporary discussions on these topics.

themes.label: Cosmological Argument
themes.gloss: Reichenbach has defended a version of the Kalam cosmological argument, focusing on the necessity of a first cause. He argues that the universe's existence requires an explanation that can only be satisfied by a transcendent cause, which he identifies as God.

themes.label: Problem of Evil
themes.gloss: In 'Evil and a Good God', Reichenbach addresses theodicy by advocating a free will defense. He posits that the existence of evil is compatible with a benevolent God, as free will is necessary for genuine moral agency.

themes.label: Faith and Reason
themes.gloss: Reichenbach explores the relationship between faith and reason, arguing that religious belief can be rationally justified. He engages with classical and contemporary arguments, emphasizing the role of logical analysis in theological discourse.

name: Grant R. Osborne
bio: Grant R. Osborne was a prominent evangelical theologian and New Testament scholar, renowned for his contributions to hermeneutics and biblical exegesis. Born in 1942, Osborne's academic journey led him to earn a Ph.D. from the University of Aberdeen, where he honed his skills in biblical interpretation.
