His seminal work, 'The Drama of Doctrine' (2005), proposes that doctrine should be understood as a script for living out the Christian faith, emphasizing the performative nature of theology. Vanhoozer's engagement with postmodern philosophy, particularly the works of Jacques Derrida and Paul Ricoeur, has shaped his approach to hermeneutics, advocating for a 'canonical-linguistic' model that prioritizes the role of Scripture within the community of faith. He has been a critical voice in the debate over inerrancy, contributing to the 'Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy' and engaging with figures like N.T. Wright and Stanley Hauerwas. Vanhoozer's work often addresses the challenges of postmodernity, urging a retrieval of classical theological resources to address contemporary issues. His contributions to the doctrine of the Trinity and the nature of divine revelation have been influential, advocating for a communicative model of God that underscores the relational aspect of divine-human interaction. Vanhoozer's academic career has been primarily associated with Trinity Evangelical Divinity School, where he has mentored a generation of theologians in the evangelical tradition.

timeline.event: Joined Trinity Evangelical Divinity School faculty

themes.label: Theodramatic Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Vanhoozer's approach to hermeneutics emphasizes the performative nature of Scripture, viewing doctrine as a script for the church's participation in God's redemptive drama.

themes.label: Canonical-Linguistic Model
themes.gloss: He advocates for a model that sees Scripture as a linguistic act within the community of faith, challenging postmodern skepticism by rooting interpretation in the canonical context.

themes.label: Doctrine of the Trinity
themes.gloss: Vanhoozer emphasizes a communicative model of the Trinity, focusing on the relational and dialogical aspects of divine revelation and human response.

name: Paul K. Moser
bio: Paul K. Moser is a contemporary American philosopher and theologian renowned for his contributions to epistemology and the philosophy of religion. Born in 1957, Moser has been a pivotal figure in advocating for a theistic epistemology that emphasizes the role of divine authority and personal transformation in the acquisition of knowledge. His work often challenges the prevailing paradigms of evidentialism and natural theology by proposing a 'Christ-shaped philosophy' that prioritizes the existential and moral dimensions of religious belief. Moser's seminal works, such as 'The Elusive God' (2008) and 'The Severity of God' (2013), critique the limitations of traditional arguments for God's existence and propose a model where divine hiddenness serves a purpose in fostering genuine human-divine relationships. Engaging with interlocutors like Alvin Plantinga and Richard Swinburne, Moser has sparked debates on the nature of evidence and the epistemic conditions for belief in God. His controversial stance on the necessity of volitional transformation for true knowledge of God has positioned him as a distinctive voice in contemporary philosophical theology. Moser's contributions extend beyond academia, influencing discussions on the practical implications of faith and reason in the modern world.

themes.label: Theistic Epistemology
themes.gloss: Moser advocates for a theistic epistemology that emphasizes divine authority and personal transformation. He argues that knowledge of God requires a volitional openness to divine moral demands, challenging traditional evidentialist approaches.

themes.label: Divine Hiddenness
themes.gloss: In 'The Elusive God,' Moser addresses the problem of divine hiddenness, suggesting that God's hiddenness serves a purpose in cultivating genuine relationships with humans. This approach reframes divine hiddenness as a positive epistemic condition.

themes.label: Christ-Shaped Philosophy
themes.gloss: Moser proposes a 'Christ-shaped philosophy' that integrates existential and moral dimensions into philosophical inquiry. This model prioritizes personal transformation and divine-human interaction over abstract metaphysical arguments.

name: Scott Hahn
bio: Scott Hahn is a prominent American Catholic theologian known for his contributions to biblical theology and Catholic apologetics. Born in 1957, Hahn was initially a Presbyterian minister before converting to Catholicism in 1986, a journey that significantly shaped his theological outlook. His conversion was influenced by his deep study of the early Church Fathers and the Catholic understanding of covenant theology. Hahn's work often engages with Protestant interlocutors, aiming to bridge theological divides through a robust scriptural exegesis. He is particularly noted for his emphasis on the covenantal structure of the Bible, a theme he explores in his seminal work, 'A Father Who Keeps His Promises' (1998). Hahn's approach is characterized by a commitment to the magisterial teachings of the Catholic Church, often drawing from the works of St. Thomas Aquinas and the Second Vatican Council. His role as a professor at the Franciscan University of Steubenville has allowed him to influence a generation of Catholic scholars and apologists. Hahn has also been involved in various controversies, particularly regarding his interpretation of the Book of Revelation and his views on the Eucharist, which have sparked dialogue and debate within both Catholic and Protestant circles. His contributions continue to be pivotal in contemporary Catholic theological discourse.

timeline.event: Joined Franciscan University of Steubenville faculty
Published 'A Father Who Keeps His Promises'

themes.label: Covenant Theology
themes.gloss: Hahn emphasizes the covenant as a central theme of biblical theology, interpreting salvation history through a series of divine covenants culminating in the New Covenant established by Christ. His work often contrasts Catholic covenantal theology with Protestant perspectives, advocating for a sacramental understanding of covenantal relationships.

themes.label: Eucharistic Theology
themes.gloss: Hahn's Eucharistic theology is deeply rooted in a literal interpretation of the Real Presence, drawing from patristic sources and the Council of Trent. He argues for the Eucharist as the fulfillment of Old Testament sacrifices, emphasizing its role in the covenantal relationship between God and humanity.

themes.label: Biblical Exegesis
themes.gloss: Hahn is known for his rigorous approach to biblical exegesis, employing typology and allegory to uncover deeper theological meanings within Scripture. His method often seeks to demonstrate the continuity between the Old and New Testaments, highlighting the unity of God's salvific plan.

name: Douglas Farrow
bio: Douglas Farrow is a prominent Canadian theologian known for his rigorous engagement with ecclesiology, sacramental theology, and political theology within the Catholic tradition. Educated at King's College London, Farrow has held a professorship at McGill University, where he has significantly contributed to contemporary theological discourse. His work often dialogues with the thought of Karl Barth, Joseph Ratzinger, and John Paul II, reflecting a deep commitment to exploring the intersections of theology and public life. Farrow's theological development is marked by a robust defense of the traditional Christian understanding of the Church's role in society, often critiquing modern secularism and advocating for a return to a more integrated vision of faith and public order. His book 'Ascension Theology' (2011) is a seminal work that re-examines the doctrine of the Ascension, arguing for its centrality in Christian theology and its implications for ecclesiology and eschatology. Farrow has also been involved in controversies surrounding the redefinition of marriage and religious freedom, positioning himself as a staunch defender of traditional Christian teachings. His contributions are characterized by a commitment to orthodoxy and a willingness to engage critically with contemporary cultural and political issues, making him a distinctive voice in modern Catholic theology.

themes.label: Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: Farrow's ecclesiology emphasizes the Church's role as a divine institution with a mission to witness to the truth in the public sphere. He critiques modern secularism and advocates for a robust engagement of the Church in societal issues.

themes.label: Sacramental Theology
themes.gloss: Farrow explores the significance of sacraments as means of grace and their role in the life of the Church, particularly focusing on the Eucharist and its implications for ecclesial unity and identity.

themes.label: Political Theology
themes.gloss: Farrow addresses the relationship between church and state, arguing for a theological vision that respects the autonomy of the Church while engaging critically with political structures.

name: Stephen C. Meyer
bio: Stephen C. Meyer is a prominent figure in the Intelligent Design movement, known for his rigorous defense of theistic interpretations of scientific phenomena. Born in 1958, Meyer earned his Ph.D. in the philosophy of science from the University of Cambridge, where he focused on the history of molecular biology and the origin of life. His work is characterized by a critical engagement with naturalistic explanations of biological complexity, positing instead that certain features of the universe and living things are best explained by an intelligent cause. Meyer's interlocutors include figures such as Richard Dawkins and Daniel Dennett, with whom he has engaged in debates over the adequacy of Darwinian mechanisms to account for the complexity of life. His books, including 'Signature in the Cell' (2009) and 'Darwin's Doubt' (2013), have sparked significant controversy and discussion within both scientific and theological circles. Meyer's contributions are distinctive for their methodological rigor and philosophical depth, challenging the prevailing materialist paradigm by advocating for a return to teleological explanations in science. His work has been instrumental in shaping contemporary apologetic discourse, particularly in the context of the science-religion dialogue.

timeline.event: Earned Ph.D. from University of Cambridge.
Co-founded the Center for Science and Culture at the Discovery Institute.

themes.label: Intelligent Design
themes.gloss: Meyer is a leading proponent of Intelligent Design, arguing that certain biological structures exhibit irreducible complexity that cannot be adequately explained by Darwinian evolution. He posits that these features are best accounted for by an intelligent cause, challenging the sufficiency of naturalistic explanations.

themes.label: Philosophy of Science
themes.gloss: Meyer's work in the philosophy of science critiques the methodological naturalism that dominates contemporary scientific inquiry. He advocates for a more open philosophical framework that allows for the consideration of teleological and theistic explanations in scientific discourse.

themes.label: Origin of Life
themes.gloss: In his exploration of the origin of life, Meyer argues against the adequacy of chemical evolutionary models. He suggests that the information-rich structures found in DNA are indicative of intelligent design, rather than the product of undirected natural processes.

themes.label: Ecumenical Theology

name: John Witte Jr.
bio: John Witte Jr. is a prominent legal historian and theologian specializing in the intersection of law, religion, and human rights. Born in 1959, Witte has significantly contributed to the understanding of how Reformation-era theological developments influenced modern legal systems. As the Robert W. Woodruff Professor of Law and the Director of the Center for the Study of Law and Religion at Emory University, he has published extensively on topics such as marriage, family law, and religious freedom. His works, including 'Law and Protestantism: The Legal Teachings of the Lutheran Reformation' (2002), explore the legal ramifications of Protestant theological innovations, particularly those of Martin Luther and John Calvin. Witte's scholarship often engages with interlocutors like Harold J. Berman, whose pioneering work on law and religion laid the groundwork for Witte's own explorations. He has been involved in controversies surrounding the role of religion in public life, advocating for a nuanced understanding of religious liberty that respects both individual rights and communal traditions. Witte's distinctive contributions lie in his ability to bridge historical insights with contemporary legal challenges, offering a robust framework for understanding the ongoing impact of religious thought on legal institutions.

timeline.event: Published 'Law and Protestantism: The Legal Teachings of the Lutheran Reformation'.
Appointed Director of the Center for the Study of Law and Religion at Emory University.
Published 'The Reformation of Rights: Law, Religion, and Human Rights in Early Modern Calvinism'.

themes.label: Law and Religion
themes.gloss: Witte examines the historical interplay between legal systems and religious doctrines, particularly focusing on how Protestant Reformation ideas have shaped modern legal frameworks.

themes.label: Marriage and Family Law
themes.gloss: He explores the theological underpinnings of marriage and family law, analyzing how religious beliefs have historically informed legal practices and continue to influence contemporary debates.

themes.label: Religious Freedom
themes.gloss: Witte advocates for a balanced approach to religious freedom, emphasizing the importance of protecting individual rights while acknowledging the role of religious communities in shaping moral and legal norms.

name: Peter J. Leithart
bio: Peter J. Leithart is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian known for his contributions to biblical theology and cultural criticism. Born in 1959, Leithart has been a significant voice in the Reformed tradition, engaging deeply with both historical and contemporary theological discourse. He earned his Ph.D. from the University of Cambridge, where he focused on the literary and theological dimensions of biblical texts. Leithart has served as a pastor and is currently the president of Theopolis Institute, an organization dedicated to the renewal of the church through biblical and liturgical studies. His works often explore the intersection of theology and culture, with a particular emphasis on the implications of Christian doctrine for societal structures. Leithart's interlocutors include figures such as N.T. Wright and James K.A. Smith, with whom he shares a commitment to a robustly biblical and sacramental vision of the church. He has been involved in controversies surrounding the Federal Vision, a theological movement within Reformed circles that emphasizes covenant theology and the objectivity of the sacraments. Leithart's distinctive contributions include his advocacy for a 'deep exegesis' approach, which integrates historical, literary, and theological readings of Scripture. His notable works include 'Deep Exegesis: The Mystery of Reading Scripture' and 'Defending Constantine: The Twilight of an Empire and the Dawn of Christendom,' where he challenges prevailing narratives about Constantine's role in Christian history.

themes.label: Biblical Theology
themes.gloss: Leithart emphasizes a holistic reading of Scripture, advocating for 'deep exegesis' that incorporates literary, historical, and theological dimensions. He argues for the unity of the biblical narrative and its implications for contemporary ecclesial practice.

themes.label: Cultural Criticism
themes.gloss: Leithart critiques modern secularism and advocates for a Christian engagement with culture that is both critical and constructive. He explores how Christian doctrine can inform and transform societal structures and cultural practices.

themes.label: Federal Vision
themes.gloss: Leithart is associated with the Federal Vision movement, which emphasizes the objectivity of the covenant and the sacraments. He argues for a more communal and covenantal understanding of salvation, challenging individualistic interpretations.

name: Christian Smith
bio: Christian Smith is a prominent American sociologist of religion whose work has significantly influenced contemporary evangelical thought. Born in 1960, Smith has been a pivotal figure in the study of religion and sociology, particularly through his exploration of religious identity and practice among American youth. His academic journey began with a focus on liberation theology, but he later shifted towards a critical analysis of evangelicalism, especially in the context of modern American society. Smith's seminal work, 'Soul Searching: The Religious and Spiritual Lives of American Teenagers' (2005), co-authored with Melinda Lundquist Denton, introduced the concept of 'Moralistic Therapeutic Deism' (MTD), a term that has since become a cornerstone in discussions about the religious beliefs of contemporary youth. His critique of MTD highlights a shift away from traditional doctrinal beliefs towards a more individualized and therapeutic spirituality. Smith's interlocutors include sociologists like Robert Wuthnow and theologians such as Stanley Hauerwas, with whom he shares a critical stance on the commodification of religion. Controversially, Smith has critiqued the secularization thesis, arguing instead for the persistent and evolving nature of religious belief in modern contexts. His contributions extend to the methodological debates in sociology, advocating for a more nuanced understanding of religious phenomena that transcends simplistic secular-religious binaries.

timeline.event: Joined University of Notre Dame faculty

themes.label: Moralistic Therapeutic Deism
themes.gloss: Smith's concept of Moralistic Therapeutic Deism describes a prevalent belief system among American youth characterized by a focus on personal happiness and a distant, non-interventionist deity.

themes.label: Critique of Secularization
themes.gloss: Smith challenges the secularization thesis, positing that religion remains a dynamic and influential force in contemporary society, contrary to predictions of its decline.

themes.label: Religious Identity Formation
themes.gloss: Smith explores how religious identities are formed and maintained in modern contexts, emphasizing the role of socialization and cultural influences on belief systems.

name: Craig S. Keener
bio: Craig S. Keener is a prominent contemporary New Testament scholar known for his extensive work on the historical and cultural contexts of the New Testament. Born in 1960, Keener has significantly contributed to evangelical scholarship, particularly through his rigorous application of historical-critical methods. His magnum opus, a four-volume commentary on Acts, exemplifies his commitment to exhaustive research and engagement with ancient sources. Keener's work often dialogues with scholars like N.T. Wright and Richard Bauckham, positioning him within a broader conversation on the historical Jesus and early Christianity. He has also been involved in discussions on the role of miracles in the New Testament, challenging both skeptical and credulous perspectives by advocating for a balanced, historically informed approach. Keener's contributions extend to the realm of intercultural hermeneutics, where he emphasizes the importance of understanding the New Testament within its original socio-cultural milieu. His scholarship is marked by a commitment to bridging academic rigor with faith-based inquiry, often addressing controversies surrounding the historical reliability of the New Testament texts. Keener's work is characterized by a meticulous attention to detail and a robust engagement with both ancient texts and contemporary scholarship, making him a pivotal figure in evangelical theological circles.

timeline.event: Published 'The IVP Bible Background Commentary: New Testament'

themes.label: Historical Contextualization
themes.gloss: Keener emphasizes the importance of understanding the New Testament within its historical and cultural contexts. His work often involves detailed analysis of ancient sources to illuminate the socio-political and religious background of the biblical texts.

themes.label: Miracles in the New Testament
themes.gloss: Keener is known for his comprehensive study on the role of miracles in the New Testament, advocating for a historically grounded approach that neither dismisses nor uncritically accepts miraculous accounts.

themes.label: Intercultural Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Keener stresses the necessity of interpreting the New Testament through the lens of its original cultural setting, arguing that modern readers must consider ancient perspectives to fully grasp the text's meaning.

name: D. Stephen Long
bio: D. Stephen Long is a prominent contemporary theologian known for his contributions to Methodist and Wesleyan theology, as well as his engagement with philosophical theology. Born in 1960, Long has been a significant figure in the dialogue between theology and philosophy, particularly through his exploration of the intersections between ethics, politics, and ecclesiology. His academic journey includes teaching positions at Marquette University, Garrett-Evangelical Theological Seminary, and Duke University, where he has influenced a generation of theologians and scholars. Long's work often engages with the thought of Thomas Aquinas, Karl Barth, and John Wesley, seeking to integrate their insights into a coherent theological framework that addresses modern ethical and political challenges. He is noted for his critical engagement with liberal theology and his advocacy for a robust ecclesial ethics that resists the secularization of Christian moral discourse. Among his notable works are 'Divine Economy: Theology and the Market' and 'The Goodness of God: Theology, Church, and the Social Order,' where he critiques the commodification of theology and argues for a return to a more communal and sacramental understanding of Christian life. Long's contributions have sparked discussions on the role of the church in public life and the necessity of a theological ethics that is deeply rooted in the Christian tradition while responsive to contemporary societal issues.

timeline.event: Published 'Divine Economy: Theology and the Market'

themes.label: Theology and Economics
themes.gloss: Long critiques the commodification of theology and advocates for a theological understanding of economics that emphasizes communal and sacramental values over market-driven ideologies.

themes.label: Ecclesial Ethics
themes.gloss: He argues for an ethics rooted in the ecclesial community, challenging the secularization of moral discourse and emphasizing the church's role in shaping ethical norms.

themes.label: Engagement with Aquinas
themes.gloss: Long engages deeply with Thomas Aquinas, integrating Thomistic insights into contemporary theological and ethical discussions, particularly in relation to virtue ethics and natural law.

name: Graham Oppy
bio: Graham Oppy is a prominent Australian philosopher and theologian, renowned for his rigorous engagement with the philosophy of religion. Born in 1960, Oppy has significantly contributed to contemporary debates on the rationality of religious belief, particularly through his critical examination of arguments for the existence of God. His work is characterized by a commitment to analytic philosophy and a focus on the logical coherence of theistic claims. Oppy is best known for his critiques of classical theistic arguments, including the cosmological, teleological, and ontological arguments, which he addresses in his seminal work, 'Arguing About Gods' (2006). His interlocutors include notable figures such as William Lane Craig, Alvin Plantinga, and Richard Swinburne, with whom he has engaged in numerous debates and discussions. Oppy's approach is marked by a methodological naturalism, which he argues provides a more parsimonious and coherent explanatory framework than theism. He has also contributed to discussions on the problem of evil, religious pluralism, and the epistemology of religious belief. Oppy's work is distinguished by its clarity, precision, and a commitment to philosophical rigor, making him a central figure in contemporary philosophical theology.

themes.label: Critique of Theistic Arguments
themes.gloss: Oppy is renowned for his systematic critique of classical theistic arguments, including cosmological, teleological, and ontological arguments. He argues that these arguments fail to provide a compelling case for theism, often highlighting logical inconsistencies and proposing naturalistic alternatives.

themes.label: Methodological Naturalism
themes.gloss: Oppy advocates for methodological naturalism, asserting that naturalistic explanations are more parsimonious and coherent than theistic ones. He argues that naturalism offers a superior explanatory framework for understanding the universe and human experience.

themes.label: Philosophy of Religion
themes.gloss: Oppy's contributions to the philosophy of religion are marked by a rigorous analytic approach. He engages with key issues such as the problem of evil, religious pluralism, and the epistemology of religious belief, often challenging the coherence and plausibility of theistic claims.

name: Gregg R. Allison
bio: Gregg R. Allison is a contemporary evangelical theologian renowned for his contributions to ecclesiology and systematic theology. Born in 1960, Allison has been a pivotal figure in the Southern Baptist tradition, serving as a professor of Christian Theology at the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary. His scholarly work is marked by a robust engagement with historical theology, particularly in dialogue with the Church Fathers and the Reformation theologians. Allison's magnum opus, 'Historical Theology: An Introduction to Christian Doctrine,' provides a comprehensive survey of doctrinal development across church history, reflecting his commitment to grounding contemporary theological reflection in historical context. He has been a significant interlocutor with Roman Catholic theology, particularly through his work 'Roman Catholic Theology and Practice: An Evangelical Assessment,' where he critically engages with Catholic doctrines from an evangelical perspective. Allison's contributions to the doctrine of the church are encapsulated in his book 'Sojourners and Strangers: The Doctrine of the Church,' where he articulates a robust ecclesiology that emphasizes the church's nature as a pilgrim community. His work often intersects with contemporary theological debates, including discussions on the nature of tradition, the role of the sacraments, and the authority of Scripture. Through his extensive writing and teaching, Allison has influenced a generation of evangelical scholars and pastors, advocating for a theology that is both historically informed and missionally engaged.

timeline.event: Published 'Historical Theology: An Introduction to Christian Doctrine'
Published 'Roman Catholic Theology and Practice: An Evangelical Assessment'
Published 'Sojourners and Strangers: The Doctrine of the Church'

themes.label: Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: Allison's ecclesiology emphasizes the church as a pilgrim community, focusing on its nature, mission, and governance. He integrates historical insights with contemporary evangelical concerns, advocating for a church that is both biblically grounded and culturally engaged.

themes.label: Historical Theology
themes.gloss: Allison's approach to historical theology involves a comprehensive survey of doctrinal development, highlighting the importance of historical context in understanding and formulating contemporary theological positions. His work serves as a bridge between past theological insights and present-day applications.

themes.label: Roman Catholic-Evangelical Dialogue
themes.gloss: In his critical engagement with Roman Catholic theology, Allison provides an evangelical assessment of Catholic doctrines, fostering dialogue while maintaining doctrinal distinctives. His work seeks to clarify evangelical positions in light of Catholic teachings, promoting mutual understanding.

name: Gregory E. Ganssle
bio: Gregory E. Ganssle is a contemporary American philosopher and theologian known for his work in philosophical theology and the philosophy of religion. Educated at Syracuse University, where he earned his Ph.D. under the supervision of William P. Alston, Ganssle has been a prominent figure in the dialogue between faith and reason. His academic career includes significant tenures at Yale University and Biola University, where he has contributed to the intellectual rigor of Christian apologetics. Ganssle's scholarship often engages with the works of Alvin Plantinga and Nicholas Wolterstorff, exploring themes of divine action, the coherence of theism, and the rationality of religious belief. His book, 'A Reasonable God: Engaging the New Face of Atheism,' addresses the challenges posed by the New Atheists, such as Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens, offering a robust defense of theism. Ganssle's work is characterized by a commitment to clarity and philosophical precision, making complex theological concepts accessible to both academic and lay audiences. His contributions to the understanding of the relationship between science and religion, particularly in the context of evolutionary theory, have been influential in contemporary debates. Ganssle's approach is marked by a conciliatory tone, seeking common ground between divergent worldviews while maintaining a firm commitment to Christian orthodoxy.

timeline.event: Joined Yale University as a lecturer
Joined Biola University as a faculty member

themes.label: Philosophy of Religion
themes.gloss: Ganssle's work in the philosophy of religion focuses on the rationality of religious belief, engaging with contemporary atheistic critiques and defending the coherence of theism through philosophical argumentation.

themes.label: Divine Action
themes.gloss: He explores the concept of divine action, particularly how God interacts with the world, addressing issues of divine intervention and the compatibility of divine action with scientific explanations.

themes.label: Faith and Reason
themes.gloss: Ganssle examines the relationship between faith and reason, arguing for their compatibility and mutual reinforcement, drawing on historical and contemporary philosophical resources to support his claims.

name: K. Scott Oliphint
bio: K. Scott Oliphint is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian, known for his work in presuppositional apologetics and his contributions to the field of Reformed epistemology. Born in 1960, Oliphint has been a significant figure at Westminster Theological Seminary, where he has served as Professor of Apologetics and Systematic Theology. His theological development is deeply influenced by Cornelius Van Til, whose presuppositional apologetic methodology Oliphint has furthered and nuanced. Oliphint's interlocutors include figures such as Alvin Plantinga and John Frame, with whom he shares a commitment to a robust Reformed epistemology while also engaging critically with their ideas. Among his notable works is 'Covenantal Apologetics: Principles and Practice in Defense of Our Faith,' where he articulates a distinctly covenantal approach to apologetics, emphasizing the necessity of presupposing the truth of Christian revelation in all areas of thought. Oliphint has been involved in various theological controversies, particularly concerning the nature of divine attributes and the doctrine of God, where he has argued for a nuanced understanding of God's immutability and simplicity. His contributions are marked by a commitment to the authority of Scripture and the confessional standards of the Reformed tradition, making him a pivotal figure in contemporary Reformed theology.

timeline.event: Continues to teach and write on Reformed apologetics

themes.label: Presuppositional Apologetics
themes.gloss: Oliphint advances Cornelius Van Til's presuppositional apologetics by emphasizing a covenantal framework. He argues that all reasoning is grounded in presuppositions that are inherently theological, advocating for the necessity of presupposing the truth of Christian revelation in all apologetic endeavors.

themes.label: Covenantal Epistemology
themes.gloss: Oliphint's epistemology is rooted in the Reformed tradition's covenantal theology. He posits that human knowledge is contingent upon the covenantal relationship between God and humanity, which shapes the way believers understand and interpret the world.

themes.label: Doctrine of God
themes.gloss: In his exploration of divine attributes, Oliphint engages with classical theism while proposing a nuanced understanding of God's immutability and simplicity. He seeks to reconcile traditional doctrines with contemporary philosophical challenges, maintaining a commitment to scriptural authority.

name: Ligon Duncan
bio: Ligon Duncan is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian, born in 1960, known for his contributions to Presbyterian ecclesiology and systematic theology. He has served as the Chancellor of Reformed Theological Seminary, where he has been influential in shaping the curriculum and theological direction of the institution. Duncan's theological development is deeply rooted in the Westminster Confession of Faith, and he is a staunch advocate for confessional integrity within the Presbyterian Church in America (PCA). His interlocutors include figures such as R.C. Sproul and John Piper, with whom he has collaborated on various theological projects, including the Together for the Gospel (T4G) conferences. Duncan has been involved in controversies surrounding the New Perspective on Paul and the Federal Vision, both of which he critiques for deviating from traditional Reformed soteriology. His distinctive contributions include a robust defense of covenant theology and a commitment to the regulative principle of worship. Duncan's work emphasizes the importance of historical theology and the continuity of Reformed thought, making him a key figure in contemporary conservative Reformed circles.

timeline.event: Ordained in the Presbyterian Church in America
Joined faculty of Reformed Theological Seminary
Became Chancellor of Reformed Theological Seminary

themes.label: Covenant Theology
themes.gloss: Duncan emphasizes the continuity of the covenant of grace throughout redemptive history, aligning with classic Reformed thought. He argues for the centrality of covenant theology in understanding the biblical narrative and its implications for ecclesiology and soteriology.

themes.label: Regulative Principle of Worship
themes.gloss: Duncan is a proponent of the regulative principle, advocating that worship practices should be strictly derived from Scripture. He critiques contemporary worship trends that deviate from this principle, emphasizing the sufficiency of Scripture in guiding corporate worship.

themes.label: Critique of the New Perspective on Paul
themes.gloss: Duncan has been a vocal critic of the New Perspective on Paul, arguing that it undermines the Reformed understanding of justification by faith alone. He defends the traditional Pauline interpretation as articulated in the Westminster Standards.

name: Mark Dever
bio: Mark Dever is a prominent American Baptist theologian and pastor, known for his influential role in the contemporary Reformed Baptist movement. Born in 1960, Dever has been a pivotal figure in promoting ecclesiology and church revitalization through his leadership at Capitol Hill Baptist Church in Washington, D.C., where he has served since 1994. A graduate of Duke University and the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, Dever's theological development has been significantly shaped by his engagement with Reformed theology and the Puritan tradition. His interlocutors include figures such as John Piper and Al Mohler, with whom he shares a commitment to conservative evangelicalism. Dever is perhaps best known for his work with 9Marks, an organization he founded to equip church leaders with resources to build biblically faithful churches. His seminal work, 'Nine Marks of a Healthy Church,' outlines his vision for church health and has sparked both acclaim and controversy, particularly regarding its emphasis on church discipline and congregational polity. Dever's contributions are marked by a robust defense of expository preaching and a commitment to the authority of Scripture, positioning him as a leading voice in the resurgence of Reformed theology within Baptist circles.

timeline.event: Became pastor of Capitol Hill Baptist Church
Published 'Nine Marks of a Healthy Church'

themes.label: Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: Dever emphasizes a Reformed Baptist ecclesiology, advocating for congregational polity and church discipline as essential marks of a healthy church. His work stresses the importance of biblical authority and the centrality of the local church in the life of believers.

themes.label: Expository Preaching
themes.gloss: Dever is a staunch advocate for expository preaching, arguing that it is the most faithful way to convey the authority of Scripture. He believes that systematic, verse-by-verse exposition ensures that the congregation receives the full counsel of God.

themes.label: Church Revitalization
themes.gloss: Through 9Marks, Dever has contributed significantly to the discourse on church revitalization, focusing on returning churches to biblical foundations. His approach involves a re-emphasis on doctrinal teaching, church membership, and leadership accountability.

name: Richard Lints
bio: Richard Lints is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian known for his contributions to theological anthropology and the intersection of theology and culture. Born in 1960, Lints has been a significant voice in the Reformed tradition, engaging deeply with questions of identity, culture, and the nature of the church. His work often dialogues with modern philosophical thought, particularly postmodernism, and he is known for his critical engagement with thinkers like Alasdair MacIntyre and Charles Taylor. Lints has contributed to the discourse on the image of God, emphasizing the relational and communal aspects of human identity as reflective of the divine nature. His book 'Identity and Idolatry: The Image of God and Its Inversion' explores the theological implications of idolatry in contemporary culture, arguing for a robust understanding of human identity grounded in the imago Dei. Lints has also been involved in discussions on the role of tradition and innovation within the church, advocating for a dynamic yet faithful engagement with cultural contexts. His academic career has been largely associated with Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary, where he has served in various capacities, including as a professor of theology. Lints's work continues to influence contemporary theological discourse, particularly in the areas of ecclesiology and cultural engagement.

timeline.event: Continues teaching at Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary

themes.label: Theological Anthropology
themes.gloss: Lints emphasizes the relational and communal dimensions of the imago Dei, arguing that human identity is fundamentally shaped by divine relationality. He critiques individualistic interpretations and stresses the importance of community in reflecting God's image.

themes.label: Theology and Culture
themes.gloss: Lints engages with cultural hermeneutics, advocating for a theology that is both contextually aware and rooted in tradition. He argues for a critical engagement with cultural narratives, drawing on thinkers like Charles Taylor to navigate the complexities of modern identity.

themes.label: Idolatry and Identity
themes.gloss: In 'Identity and Idolatry,' Lints explores the inversion of the image of God through idolatry, proposing that contemporary cultural idols distort human identity. He calls for a return to a theologically grounded understanding of self, free from cultural idolatries.

name: Craig Bartholomew
bio: Craig Bartholomew is a prominent contemporary theologian known for his contributions to neo-Calvinist thought and biblical hermeneutics. Born in 1961, Bartholomew has been influential in integrating philosophical and theological insights into biblical studies. He has served as the Director of the Kirby Laing Institute for Christian Ethics and has held academic positions at Redeemer University and the University of Gloucestershire. Bartholomew's work is characterized by a robust engagement with the Reformed tradition, particularly through the lens of neo-Calvinism, drawing on the insights of Abraham Kuyper and Herman Dooyeweerd. His interlocutors include N.T. Wright, Richard Bauckham, and Al Wolters, with whom he shares a commitment to the authority of Scripture and the cultural mandate. Bartholomew's distinctive contributions include his advocacy for a narrative approach to biblical interpretation, emphasizing the Bible as a unified story of God's redemptive work. His works, such as 'The Drama of Scripture' co-authored with Michael Goheen, have been pivotal in shaping contemporary evangelical hermeneutics. Bartholomew has also engaged in controversies surrounding the historical-critical method, advocating for a hermeneutic that respects the historical context while affirming the theological unity of Scripture. His scholarship continues to influence debates on the role of Scripture in public theology and the integration of faith and learning.

timeline.event: Published 'The Drama of Scripture' with Michael Goheen
Appointed Director of the Kirby Laing Institute for Christian Ethics

themes.label: Narrative Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Bartholomew emphasizes the Bible as a coherent narrative, advocating for a reading that sees Scripture as a unified story of redemption. His approach challenges fragmented interpretations and seeks to integrate biblical theology with contemporary cultural engagement.

themes.label: Neo-Calvinism
themes.gloss: Drawing on Kuyperian thought, Bartholomew advances a neo-Calvinist perspective that emphasizes the sovereignty of God over all aspects of life. He argues for the relevance of Reformed theology in addressing modern cultural and ethical issues.

themes.label: Public Theology
themes.gloss: Bartholomew is a proponent of public theology, advocating for the active engagement of Christian thought in public discourse. He argues for a theology that is both biblically grounded and culturally relevant, addressing societal challenges with theological insight.

name: Hans Boersma
bio: Hans Boersma is a contemporary theologian known for his work in sacramental theology and the retrieval of patristic and medieval thought within an evangelical framework. Born in 1961 in the Netherlands, Boersma has become a prominent voice in theological circles, particularly through his emphasis on the 'sacramental ontology,' which seeks to recover a participatory understanding of reality as seen in the Church Fathers. His academic career has been marked by significant contributions to the dialogue between Protestant and Catholic theological traditions, often engaging with figures such as Henri de Lubac and Hans Urs von Balthasar. Boersma's work is characterized by a critique of modernity's secularizing tendencies, advocating instead for a return to a more integrated vision of faith and reason. His notable works include 'Heavenly Participation: The Weaving of a Sacramental Tapestry' (2011) and 'Seeing God: The Beatific Vision in Christian Tradition' (2018). Boersma has faced some controversy, particularly from those who view his sacramental emphasis as a departure from traditional evangelical positions. Nevertheless, his contributions continue to influence discussions on the nature of theological interpretation and the role of tradition in contemporary faith practice. Currently, Boersma holds the Chair to the Order of St. Benedict Servants of Christ Endowed Professorship in Ascetical Theology at Nashotah House.

themes.label: Sacramental Ontology
themes.gloss: Boersma advocates for a sacramental ontology that emphasizes the participatory nature of reality, drawing heavily on patristic and medieval sources to argue for a vision of creation as a means of divine encounter.

themes.label: Theological Retrieval
themes.gloss: Boersma engages in theological retrieval, seeking to bring the insights of pre-modern theologians into dialogue with contemporary issues, particularly focusing on figures like Gregory of Nyssa and Augustine.

themes.label: Critique of Modernity
themes.gloss: He critiques modernity's secularizing tendencies, arguing for a reintegration of faith and reason, and challenges the fragmentation of knowledge that characterizes much of modern thought.

name: Herman Selderhuis
bio: Herman Selderhuis is a prominent Dutch theologian and church historian, renowned for his expertise in Reformation studies, particularly focusing on John Calvin and Martin Luther. Born in 1961, Selderhuis has significantly contributed to the understanding of Reformed theology through his scholarly works and leadership roles. He serves as a professor of Church History and Church Polity at the Theological University of Apeldoorn and is the director of Refo500, an international platform for knowledge, expertise, ideas, products, and events related to the Reformation. Selderhuis's scholarship is marked by a meticulous examination of primary sources, offering fresh insights into the theological and ecclesiastical developments of the 16th century. His book, 'Calvin's Theology of the Psalms,' is a seminal work that explores Calvin's exegetical methods and theological reflections, emphasizing the practical and pastoral dimensions of Calvin's thought. Selderhuis engages with contemporary theological discourse by addressing the relevance of Reformation principles in modern ecclesial contexts. His work often dialogues with other Reformation scholars, such as Heiko Oberman and Richard Muller, contributing to ongoing debates about the continuity and discontinuity of Reformed theology. Selderhuis's contributions extend beyond academia as he actively participates in ecumenical dialogues, advocating for a historically informed approach to contemporary theological challenges.

timeline.event: Appointed professor at Theological University of Apeldoorn

themes.label: Calvin's Exegesis
themes.gloss: Selderhuis's work on John Calvin's exegesis of the Psalms highlights Calvin's pastoral and practical approach to scripture, emphasizing the reformer's focus on the applicability of biblical texts to the believer's life.

themes.label: Reformation (1500 - 1599) Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: Selderhuis explores the ecclesiological developments during the Reformation, particularly the shift towards a more congregational and participatory church structure, as influenced by Calvin and Luther.

themes.label: Historical Theology
themes.gloss: Selderhuis contributes to historical theology by examining the continuity and change within Reformed traditions, arguing for a nuanced understanding of doctrinal development from the Reformation to contemporary times.

name: Ian Paul
bio: Ian Paul is a contemporary Anglican theologian known for his engagement with biblical exegesis and ecclesial praxis. Born in 1961, Paul has contributed significantly to the discourse on biblical interpretation within the Anglican tradition. He completed his doctoral studies at the University of Nottingham, focusing on the Book of Revelation, which laid the groundwork for his subsequent theological inquiries. As an academic and practitioner, Paul has served as a tutor in New Testament studies at St John's College, Nottingham, and has been involved in various ecclesiastical roles, including as a member of the General Synod of the Church of England. His interlocutors include notable figures such as N.T. Wright and Richard Bauckham, with whom he shares a commitment to robust biblical scholarship. Paul has been a vocal participant in contemporary theological debates, particularly concerning issues of sexuality and church polity, often advocating for a traditionalist perspective grounded in scriptural authority. His distinctive contributions include a nuanced approach to apocalyptic literature and a critical engagement with hermeneutical methodologies. Through his writings and public engagements, Paul has sought to bridge the gap between academic theology and church life, emphasizing the relevance of biblical texts to contemporary Christian practice.

timeline.event: Completed doctoral studies at University of Nottingham
Joined St John's College, Nottingham as a tutor
Elected to the General Synod of the Church of England

themes.label: Biblical Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Ian Paul emphasizes a hermeneutical approach that integrates historical-critical methods with theological exegesis, advocating for a reading of Scripture that is both contextually informed and theologically robust.

themes.label: Apocalyptic Literature
themes.gloss: Paul's work on the Book of Revelation highlights the theological and pastoral implications of apocalyptic texts, arguing for their relevance in contemporary ecclesial contexts and their role in shaping Christian eschatological hope.

themes.label: Ecclesial Praxis
themes.gloss: In his engagement with church polity, Paul argues for a model of church governance that is deeply rooted in scriptural principles, advocating for a balance between tradition and contemporary challenges.

name: J. Gary Millar
bio: J. Gary Millar is a prominent contemporary evangelical theologian and biblical scholar, primarily known for his contributions to Old Testament studies and biblical theology. Born in 1961, Millar has been a significant figure in the evangelical tradition, particularly within the Australian context. He serves as the Principal of Queensland Theological College in Brisbane, where he has been influential in shaping theological education and pastoral training. Millar's scholarly work often engages with the theological implications of the Old Testament, with a particular focus on the books of Deuteronomy and the Psalms. His book 'Now Choose Life: Theology and Ethics in Deuteronomy' is a seminal work that explores the covenantal and ethical dimensions of Deuteronomy, arguing for its relevance in contemporary Christian ethics. Millar has also been involved in the Gospel Coalition, contributing to discussions on biblical theology and pastoral ministry. His interlocutors include scholars such as D.A. Carson and Tim Chester, with whom he shares a commitment to evangelical orthodoxy and the authority of Scripture. Millar's work is characterized by a robust engagement with biblical texts, a commitment to theological clarity, and a pastoral concern for the church's mission in the world. He is also noted for his contributions to the understanding of biblical prayer, as seen in his co-authored work 'Calling on the Name of the Lord: A Biblical Theology of Prayer'.

timeline.event: Appointed Principal of Queensland Theological College
Published 'Now Choose Life: Theology and Ethics in Deuteronomy'
Co-authored 'Calling on the Name of the Lord: A Biblical Theology of Prayer'

themes.label: Deuteronomic Theology
themes.gloss: Millar's work on Deuteronomy emphasizes its covenantal framework and ethical imperatives, arguing for its continued relevance in Christian ethical discourse. He explores the theological themes of covenant, law, and life, advocating for a reading that sees Deuteronomy as central to understanding biblical ethics.

themes.label: Biblical Theology of Prayer
themes.gloss: In 'Calling on the Name of the Lord', Millar examines the development of prayer throughout the biblical narrative, highlighting its theological significance and practical implications for contemporary Christian practice. He argues for a holistic understanding of prayer as a response to God's revelation.

themes.label: Evangelical Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Millar is committed to a hermeneutic that upholds the authority and sufficiency of Scripture. His approach is characterized by a careful exegesis of biblical texts, informed by historical and theological contexts, aiming to bridge the gap between ancient texts and modern application.

name: James Wetzel
bio: James Wetzel is a contemporary philosopher and theologian known for his work on Augustine and the intersection of philosophy and theology. Born in 1961, Wetzel has been a prominent figure in the study of Augustinian thought, particularly focusing on the themes of memory, time, and the self. He has engaged deeply with Augustine's 'Confessions,' offering a nuanced interpretation that highlights the existential and phenomenological dimensions of Augustine's work. Wetzel's scholarship is marked by a critical dialogue with both classical and modern thinkers, including Plato, Aristotle, and Heidegger, as he seeks to bridge ancient philosophical insights with contemporary existential questions. His work often explores the tension between faith and reason, emphasizing the role of narrative and memory in the formation of identity. Wetzel has also contributed to discussions on the nature of evil and the problem of suffering, drawing on Augustine's theodicy while engaging with modern critiques. As a professor at Villanova University, Wetzel has influenced a generation of students and scholars, fostering a rigorous yet accessible approach to philosophical theology. His contributions extend beyond academia, as he actively participates in public discourse on the relevance of Augustinian thought in addressing modern existential and ethical dilemmas.

timeline.event: Published first major work on Augustine
Published influential book on memory and identity

themes.label: Augustinian Memory
themes.gloss: Wetzel explores Augustine's concept of memory as a foundational element of personal identity, emphasizing its role in the continuity of self and its existential implications.

themes.label: Faith and Reason
themes.gloss: Wetzel engages with the classical tension between faith and reason, advocating for a synthesis that respects the integrity of both theological and philosophical inquiry.

themes.label: Theodicy and Evil
themes.gloss: Wetzel examines Augustine's theodicy, addressing the problem of evil with a focus on the narrative and existential dimensions of suffering and divine justice.

name: Jens SchrÃ¶ter
bio: Jens SchrÃ¶ter is a prominent German theologian and New Testament scholar, renowned for his contributions to the historical-critical method and his exploration of early Christianity's development. Born in 1961, SchrÃ¶ter has been a pivotal figure in contemporary theological discourse, particularly through his academic tenure at Humboldt University of Berlin. His scholarly work often engages with the historical Jesus, the formation of the New Testament canon, and the interplay between history and theology. SchrÃ¶ter's critical approach is characterized by a rigorous analysis of textual and historical contexts, aiming to reconstruct the socio-religious milieu of early Christian communities. His interlocutors include notable scholars such as Martin Hengel and E.P. Sanders, with whom he shares a commitment to historical rigor and methodological precision. SchrÃ¶ter has also been involved in debates concerning the theological implications of historical-critical findings, often challenging traditional dogmatic interpretations. His publications, including 'From Jesus to the New Testament' and 'Jesus of Nazareth: Jew from Galilee, Savior of the World,' reflect his nuanced understanding of the complex relationship between historical inquiry and theological reflection. SchrÃ¶ter's work continues to influence contemporary theological scholarship, offering fresh insights into the origins and development of Christian thought.

themes.label: Historical Jesus
themes.gloss: SchrÃ¶ter's work on the historical Jesus focuses on reconstructing the life and teachings of Jesus within the socio-political context of first-century Palestine. He emphasizes the Jewishness of Jesus and the implications of this for understanding early Christian identity.

themes.label: New Testament Canon Formation
themes.gloss: SchrÃ¶ter investigates the processes and criteria that led to the formation of the New Testament canon, highlighting the diversity of early Christian writings and the theological debates that influenced canonical decisions.

themes.label: Interplay of History and Theology
themes.gloss: SchrÃ¶ter explores the dynamic relationship between historical research and theological interpretation, arguing for a critical engagement that respects historical findings while considering their theological significance.

name: Paul R. Williamson
bio: Paul R. Williamson is a contemporary British theologian known for his contributions to evangelical biblical scholarship, particularly in the realm of Old Testament studies. Educated at Moore Theological College and the University of Cambridge, Williamson has focused extensively on the covenantal themes within the Hebrew Scriptures. His work often engages with the theological implications of biblical covenants, exploring their continuity and discontinuity across the Testaments. Williamson's scholarship is marked by a rigorous exegetical approach, often interacting with both historical-critical methodologies and evangelical hermeneutics. He has contributed significantly to discussions on the Abrahamic and Mosaic covenants, offering a nuanced perspective that challenges both traditional dispensational and covenantal frameworks. His interlocutors include scholars such as N.T. Wright and John Goldingay, with whom he shares a commitment to integrating historical context with theological interpretation. Williamson's distinctive contribution lies in his ability to bridge the gap between academic biblical scholarship and practical theology, making his work accessible to both scholars and laypersons. His publications, including 'Sealed with an Oath: Covenant in Godâ€™s Unfolding Purpose', have been influential in shaping contemporary evangelical thought on biblical covenants.

timeline.event: Completed PhD at the University of Cambridge
Published 'Sealed with an Oath: Covenant in Godâ€™s Unfolding Purpose'

themes.label: Covenantal Theology
themes.gloss: Williamson's work on covenantal theology emphasizes the continuity and discontinuity of biblical covenants, particularly focusing on the Abrahamic and Mosaic covenants. He challenges traditional dispensational and covenantal frameworks, advocating for a nuanced understanding that respects the historical and theological contexts of the covenants.

themes.label: Old Testament Exegesis
themes.gloss: Williamson is noted for his exegetical work on the Old Testament, employing historical-critical methods within an evangelical framework. His analysis often seeks to uncover the theological implications of Old Testament narratives, particularly in relation to covenantal themes.

themes.label: Biblical Theology
themes.gloss: In his approach to biblical theology, Williamson integrates historical context with theological interpretation, aiming to make the biblical text relevant to contemporary evangelical thought. His work often addresses the unfolding purpose of God as revealed through the biblical covenants.

name: Peter Enns
bio: Peter Enns is a contemporary American biblical scholar and theologian known for his contributions to the dialogue between evangelicalism and historical-critical methodologies. Born in 1961, Enns has been a pivotal figure in challenging traditional evangelical approaches to Scripture, advocating for a more nuanced understanding that embraces historical context and literary forms. His tenure at Westminster Theological Seminary was marked by controversy, particularly surrounding his book 'Inspiration and Incarnation' (2005), which argued for an incarnational model of Scripture that parallels the divine and human natures of Christ. This work led to significant debate within the Reformed community and ultimately to his departure from Westminster in 2008. Enns has since continued his academic career at Eastern University, where he has further developed his theological perspectives. His interlocutors include conservative theologians who uphold inerrancy, as well as progressive scholars who seek to reconcile faith with modern critical scholarship. Enns' distinctive contributions lie in his emphasis on the Bible as an ancient text that must be understood within its cultural milieu, and his advocacy for a faith that is open to questions and uncertainties. Through works like 'The Bible Tells Me So' (2014) and 'The Sin of Certainty' (2016), Enns has encouraged believers to embrace a faith that is dynamic and evolving.

themes.label: Incarnational Model of Scripture
themes.gloss: Enns proposes that the Bible should be understood as both divine and human, akin to the dual nature of Christ. This model suggests that Scripture is a product of its historical and cultural context, challenging traditional views of inerrancy.

themes.label: Historical-Critical Methodology
themes.gloss: Enns advocates for the integration of historical-critical methods in biblical interpretation, arguing that understanding the ancient Near Eastern context is essential for grasping the intended meaning of biblical texts.

themes.label: Faith and Doubt
themes.gloss: Enns emphasizes the importance of embracing doubt and uncertainty in the Christian faith journey. He contends that questioning and wrestling with difficult theological issues can lead to a more robust and authentic faith.

name: R. Scott Clark
bio: R. Scott Clark is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian known for his rigorous defense of confessional Reformed orthodoxy. Born in 1961, Clark has been a significant voice in the Reformed tradition, particularly through his work at Westminster Seminary California, where he has served as a professor of church history and historical theology. His scholarship often engages with the historical development of Reformed theology, emphasizing the importance of the Reformed confessions as a means of preserving theological integrity. Clark has been a vocal critic of the Federal Vision theology, arguing that it undermines the doctrine of justification by faith alone. He has also engaged with the New Perspective on Paul, defending the traditional Reformed understanding of Pauline theology. His notable works include 'Recovering the Reformed Confession,' where he advocates for a return to the historic confessions as a means of maintaining doctrinal purity. Clark's contributions extend to his active online presence, where he disseminates Reformed theology through blogs and podcasts, making complex theological concepts accessible to a broader audience. His interlocutors often include figures like N.T. Wright and proponents of the Federal Vision, against whom he defends the classical Reformed positions.

timeline.event: Became a prominent critic of the Federal Vision theology
Continues to teach at Westminster Seminary California

themes.label: Confessional Reformed Orthodoxy
themes.gloss: Clark emphasizes the necessity of adhering to the historic Reformed confessions as a safeguard against theological drift, advocating for their centrality in Reformed identity and practice.

themes.label: Critique of Federal Vision
themes.gloss: Clark is a leading critic of the Federal Vision movement, arguing that it compromises the doctrine of justification by faith alone and deviates from traditional Reformed soteriology.

themes.label: Defense of Classical Reformed Theology
themes.gloss: Through his writings and teachings, Clark defends the classical Reformed understanding of doctrines such as covenant theology and justification, often engaging with contemporary theological movements that challenge these views.

name: Gilles Emery
bio: Gilles Emery is a contemporary Swiss theologian renowned for his contributions to Thomistic theology, particularly in the realm of Trinitarian doctrine. Born in 1962, Emery has established himself as a leading figure in the study of St. Thomas Aquinas, engaging deeply with the medieval scholastic tradition while addressing modern theological questions. A Dominican priest, Emery's work is characterized by a rigorous adherence to the principles of Thomism, yet he remains open to dialogue with other theological traditions and contemporary philosophical thought. His major works include 'The Trinitarian Theology of St. Thomas Aquinas' and 'The Trinity: An Introduction to Catholic Doctrine on the Triune God,' which have been pivotal in reviving interest in Thomistic Trinitarian theology. Emery's interlocutors include both historical figures such as Augustine and Bonaventure, as well as contemporary theologians like Karl Rahner and Hans Urs von Balthasar. He has been involved in various theological controversies, particularly those concerning the interpretation of Aquinas's views on the Trinity and the nature of divine simplicity. Emery's distinctive contribution lies in his ability to elucidate complex theological concepts with clarity and precision, making the rich tradition of Thomism accessible to a modern audience while maintaining its doctrinal integrity.

timeline.event: Published 'The Trinitarian Theology of St. Thomas Aquinas'
Published 'The Trinity: An Introduction to Catholic Doctrine on the Triune God'
Appointed professor at the University of Fribourg

themes.label: Trinitarian Theology
themes.gloss: Emery's work on Trinitarian theology is marked by a deep engagement with Aquinas's synthesis of the Trinity, emphasizing the relational distinctions within the Godhead while maintaining divine simplicity. He argues for a nuanced understanding of the processions and relations in God, drawing heavily on Aquinas's metaphysical framework.

themes.label: Divine Simplicity
themes.gloss: Emery defends the Thomistic doctrine of divine simplicity, which posits that God's essence and existence are identical, against modern critiques. He articulates how this doctrine is foundational for understanding the unity and attributes of God, particularly in relation to the Trinity.

themes.label: Thomistic Revival
themes.gloss: Through his scholarly work, Emery has played a significant role in the contemporary revival of Thomism, particularly in the context of Trinitarian and systematic theology. His efforts have been instrumental in re-establishing Aquinas as a central figure in modern theological discourse.

name: James R. White
bio: James R. White is a prominent Reformed theologian and apologist known for his rigorous defense of Christian orthodoxy and his engagement in public debates. Born in 1962, White has been a central figure in contemporary apologetics, particularly through his work with Alpha and Omega Ministries, which he founded. His theological development is deeply rooted in Reformed traditions, with a strong emphasis on the doctrines of grace and the authority of Scripture. White has engaged in numerous debates with figures such as Bart Ehrman, a noted New Testament scholar, and Shabir Ally, a prominent Muslim apologist, showcasing his commitment to defending the Christian faith against critical scholarship and interfaith challenges. Controversially, White has been a vocal critic of Roman Catholicism, particularly in his book 'The Roman Catholic Controversy,' where he challenges Catholic doctrines from a Reformed perspective. His distinctive contributions include a robust defense of the doctrine of the Trinity and the reliability of the New Testament manuscripts. White's work is characterized by a commitment to sola scriptura and a presuppositional apologetic approach, making him a significant voice in contemporary evangelical and Reformed circles.

timeline.event: Debated Bart Ehrman on textual criticism

themes.label: Sola Scriptura
themes.gloss: White is a staunch advocate of sola scriptura, emphasizing the Bible as the sole infallible rule of faith. He argues against traditions that elevate church authority or additional revelations to the level of Scripture, particularly critiquing Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox positions.

themes.label: Trinitarian Theology
themes.gloss: White defends the orthodox doctrine of the Trinity against both historical and contemporary challenges. He engages with anti-Trinitarian groups, such as Jehovah's Witnesses and Oneness Pentecostals, providing exegetical and historical arguments for the co-equality and co-eternality of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

themes.label: Textual Criticism
themes.gloss: In his work on textual criticism, White argues for the reliability of the New Testament manuscripts. He engages with scholars like Bart Ehrman, defending the textual integrity of the New Testament against claims of corruption and textual instability.

name: Katherine Sonderegger
bio: Katherine Sonderegger is a prominent contemporary theologian known for her rigorous engagement with systematic theology, particularly within the Anglican tradition. Born in 1962, Sonderegger has significantly contributed to the field through her innovative approach to the doctrine of God. Her magnum opus, 'Systematic Theology: Volume 1, The Doctrine of God' (2015), marks a pivotal shift in theological discourse by emphasizing the unity of God over the traditional focus on the Trinity. Sonderegger challenges the prevailing trends in modern theology that prioritize relationality and social trinitarianism, arguing instead for a return to the classical attributes of God such as omnipotence, omniscience, and omnipresence. Her work is deeply influenced by Karl Barth, yet she diverges from Barthian Christocentrism by advocating for a more robust doctrine of divine simplicity. Sonderegger's theological method is characterized by a commitment to scriptural exegesis and a critical engagement with historical theological sources, including Augustine and Aquinas. Her contributions have sparked considerable debate, particularly regarding her critique of the social doctrine of the Trinity, positioning her as a leading voice in contemporary Anglican theology. Sonderegger continues to teach at Virginia Theological Seminary, where she influences a new generation of theologians through her scholarship and pedagogy.

timeline.event: Published 'Systematic Theology: Volume 1, The Doctrine of God'
Continues teaching at Virginia Theological Seminary

themes.label: Doctrine of God
themes.gloss: Sonderegger emphasizes the unity and simplicity of God, challenging the modern theological focus on the Trinity. Her work advocates for a return to classical attributes, arguing that God's oneness is foundational to understanding divine nature.

themes.label: Critique of Social Trinitarianism
themes.gloss: Sonderegger critiques the contemporary emphasis on relationality within the Trinity, arguing that it undermines the classical understanding of God's unity. She calls for a theological reorientation that prioritizes divine simplicity over relational models.

themes.label: Engagement with Classical Theologians
themes.gloss: Her work is marked by a deep engagement with historical figures like Augustine and Aquinas, using their insights to inform contemporary theological debates. Sonderegger's method involves a critical retrieval of classical doctrines to address modern issues.

name: William Cavanaugh
bio: William Cavanaugh is a prominent contemporary Catholic theologian known for his incisive critiques of modern political and economic structures through a theological lens. Born in 1962, Cavanaugh has significantly contributed to discussions on the intersection of theology and politics, particularly through his analysis of the concept of the 'state' and its theological implications. His seminal work, 'The Myth of Religious Violence' (2009), challenges the notion that religion is inherently prone to violence, arguing instead that this myth serves to legitimize secular violence. Cavanaugh's engagement with the works of Augustine, as well as his dialogue with liberation theology, has shaped his understanding of the Church as a counter-political community. His critique of consumer capitalism is articulated in 'Being Consumed: Economics and Christian Desire' (2008), where he explores how market ideologies shape human desires and community life. Cavanaugh's theological project is deeply influenced by post-liberal theology, particularly the works of Stanley Hauerwas and John Milbank, with whom he shares a commitment to the Church's role as an alternative polis. His contributions continue to provoke debate on the role of the Church in public life, the nature of secularism, and the ethical dimensions of economic practices.

timeline.event: Published 'Being Consumed: Economics and Christian Desire'
Joined DePaul University as a professor

themes.label: The Myth of Religious Violence
themes.gloss: Cavanaugh critiques the narrative that religion is uniquely prone to violence, arguing that this myth is used to justify secular state violence and marginalize religious voices in public discourse.

themes.label: Church as Counter-Political Community
themes.gloss: Drawing on Augustine, Cavanaugh envisions the Church as an alternative polis that resists the coercive power of the state and embodies a different form of social and political order.

themes.label: Critique of Consumer Capitalism
themes.gloss: In 'Being Consumed', Cavanaugh examines how consumer capitalism shapes desires and community, advocating for a Christian economic ethic that prioritizes human flourishing over market efficiency.

name: Brad Gregory
bio: Brad Gregory is a contemporary Catholic historian and theologian whose work critically examines the interplay between religion and modernity. Educated at the University of Notre Dame, Gregory has become a prominent voice in the study of the Reformation and its enduring impact on Western thought. His seminal work, 'The Unintended Reformation: How a Religious Revolution Secularized Society' (2012), argues that the Reformation's fragmentation of religious authority inadvertently paved the way for secular modernity. Gregory engages with figures such as Martin Luther and John Calvin, scrutinizing their theological innovations and societal implications. His scholarship often intersects with the works of Charles Taylor, particularly in exploring the secularization thesis. Gregory's contributions are marked by a critical stance towards the Enlightenment's legacy, positing that the Reformation's doctrinal pluralism led to the relativism and individualism characteristic of contemporary Western society. His work is not without controversy; critics argue that Gregory's narrative oversimplifies the complex historical processes leading to modern secularism. Nonetheless, his interdisciplinary approach, blending history, theology, and philosophy, offers a nuanced critique of modernity's religious and cultural underpinnings.

timeline.event: Joined University of Notre Dame faculty

themes.label: Reformation (1500 - 1599) and Modernity
themes.gloss: Gregory examines the Reformation's role in shaping modern secular society, arguing that the fragmentation of religious authority during the Reformation set the stage for secularization and individualism.

themes.label: Secularization Thesis
themes.gloss: Engaging with Charles Taylor's work, Gregory critiques the secularization thesis, suggesting that the Reformation's unintended consequences include the erosion of religious authority and the rise of secular modernity.

themes.label: Religious Pluralism
themes.gloss: Gregory explores how the Reformation's doctrinal diversity contributed to contemporary religious pluralism, which he views as both a cause and effect of modern secularism.

name: Craig D. Allert
bio: Craig D. Allert is a contemporary Canadian theologian known for his contributions to evangelical theology, particularly in the context of patristic studies and the development of early Christian thought. Born in 1963, Allert has been a prominent figure in bridging the gap between evangelicalism and the early church fathers. His academic journey has been largely associated with Trinity Western University, where he has served as a professor of religious studies. Allert's work often engages with the writings of early church fathers, emphasizing the importance of historical context in theological interpretation. His book, 'A High View of Scripture? The Authority of the Bible and the Formation of the New Testament Canon,' challenges evangelical assumptions about the formation of the biblical canon, arguing for a nuanced understanding that considers the historical and ecclesiastical processes involved. Allert's scholarship is marked by a commitment to integrating historical-critical methods with evangelical theology, often engaging with interlocutors such as Bruce Metzger and F.F. Bruce. He has been involved in discussions about the authority of scripture, the role of tradition, and the development of doctrine, contributing to contemporary debates on these issues. His work is characterized by a careful examination of primary sources and a willingness to question established evangelical positions, making him a distinctive voice in the field.

timeline.event: Joined faculty at Trinity Western University

themes.label: Authority of Scripture
themes.gloss: Allert critically examines the evangelical understanding of biblical authority, advocating for a perspective that acknowledges the historical and ecclesiastical processes in the formation of the canon. His work challenges simplistic views and calls for a more historically informed approach.

themes.label: Patristic (100 - 749) Engagement
themes.gloss: Allert emphasizes the importance of engaging with early church fathers to enrich evangelical theology. He argues that understanding the historical context of early Christian writings can provide valuable insights for contemporary theological discussions.

themes.label: Canon Formation
themes.gloss: In his exploration of the New Testament canon, Allert argues against the notion of a fixed, early-established canon, suggesting instead a dynamic process influenced by various historical and theological factors. His work invites evangelicals to reconsider traditional narratives about canonization.

name: Michael S. Heiser
bio: Michael S. Heiser was an influential American biblical scholar and theologian known for his work in the field of ancient Near Eastern studies and its implications for biblical interpretation. Born in 1963, Heiser earned his Ph.D. in Hebrew Bible and Semitic Languages from the University of Wisconsin-Madison. His scholarly pursuits were deeply rooted in the intersection of ancient texts and contemporary evangelical theology. Heiser's most notable contribution is his work on the divine council worldview, which he articulated in his seminal book, 'The Unseen Realm: Recovering the Supernatural Worldview of the Bible' (2015). This work challenged traditional evangelical readings by emphasizing the plurality of divine beings in the Hebrew Bible, a concept often overlooked in mainstream theology. Heiser engaged with the works of scholars like John Walton and N.T. Wright, while also addressing critiques from more conservative theologians who viewed his interpretations as controversial.
