His book, 'Justification and the New Perspectives on Paul,' is a seminal critique of this movement, emphasizing the forensic nature of justification. Waters is also noted for his work on ecclesiology, particularly in the context of Presbyterian polity, where he has articulated a robust defense of confessional standards and the regulative principle of worship. His contributions extend to the field of biblical theology, where he has explored the covenantal framework of Scripture, arguing for its centrality in understanding redemptive history. Waters' scholarship is characterized by a commitment to the authority of Scripture and the confessional heritage of the Reformed tradition.

timeline.event: Published 'Justification and the New Perspectives on Paul'

themes.label: New Perspective on Paul
themes.gloss: Waters critiques the New Perspective on Paul, emphasizing traditional Reformed views on justification. He argues against the reinterpretation of Paul's writings that downplay the forensic aspect of justification, engaging with scholars like N.T. Wright and James D.G. Dunn.

themes.label: Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: Waters focuses on Presbyterian polity, defending the confessional standards and the regulative principle of worship. He articulates a vision of church governance that aligns with historic Reformed principles, emphasizing the authority of Scripture in ecclesiastical matters.

themes.label: Covenantal Theology
themes.gloss: Waters underscores the importance of the covenantal framework in biblical theology. He argues that understanding Scripture through the lens of covenant is essential for grasping the unity and progression of redemptive history.

name: Matthew S. Harmon
bio: Matthew S. Harmon is a contemporary American theologian and biblical scholar, primarily associated with the evangelical tradition. He has made significant contributions to New Testament studies, particularly in the area of Pauline theology. Harmon is known for his rigorous exegetical work and his ability to engage with both historical-critical methods and contemporary theological discourse. His scholarship often dialogues with prominent figures such as N.T. Wright, James D.G. Dunn, and Richard B. Hays, particularly in the realm of Pauline interpretation. Harmonâ€™s work is characterized by a commitment to the authority of Scripture and a focus on the practical implications of biblical theology for the church today. His book, 'Philippians: A Mentor Commentary,' exemplifies his exegetical precision and theological depth, offering insights into the text's historical context and its application for contemporary faith communities. Harmon has also contributed to discussions on the New Perspective on Paul, critically engaging with its proponents while maintaining a traditional evangelical stance. His teaching and writing continue to influence students and scholars within the evangelical academy, emphasizing the transformative power of the gospel and the centrality of Christ in biblical interpretation.

timeline.event: Joined faculty at Grace College and Theological Seminary
Continued contributions to Pauline studies and evangelical theology

themes.label: Pauline Theology
themes.gloss: Harmon engages deeply with the theology of the Apostle Paul, emphasizing the centrality of the gospel and the transformative power of Christ's work. He critically interacts with the New Perspective on Paul, maintaining a traditional evangelical interpretation while acknowledging the insights of contemporary scholarship.

themes.label: Biblical Exegesis
themes.gloss: Harmon is noted for his meticulous exegetical work, particularly in the New Testament. His approach combines historical-critical methods with theological reflection, aiming to uncover the text's original meaning and its relevance for today's church.

themes.label: Scriptural Authority
themes.gloss: A hallmark of Harmon's theology is his unwavering commitment to the authority of Scripture. He argues for the Bible's central role in shaping doctrine and practice, advocating for a hermeneutic that is both faithful to the text and applicable to modern contexts.

name: Michael Kruger
bio: Michael Kruger is a prominent contemporary evangelical theologian, specializing in New Testament studies and the canon of Scripture. Born in 1972, Kruger has significantly contributed to the understanding of the formation and authority of the New Testament canon. He serves as the President and Professor of New Testament and Early Christianity at Reformed Theological Seminary in Charlotte, North Carolina. Kruger's scholarly work often engages with the historical-critical method, defending the traditional evangelical view of the canon against critical scholarship. His notable works include 'Canon Revisited: Establishing the Origins and Authority of the New Testament Books' (2012) and 'The Question of Canon: Challenging the Status Quo in the New Testament Debate' (2013). Kruger frequently dialogues with scholars such as Bart Ehrman, critiquing the latter's skeptical approach to the New Testament's reliability. Kruger's contributions are marked by a robust defense of the self-authenticating model of the canon, arguing that the New Testament books possess intrinsic authority recognized by the early church. His work also addresses the criteria of canonicity, emphasizing the role of apostolicity, orthodoxy, and catholicity. Kruger remains a pivotal figure in evangelical scholarship, advocating for a historically grounded yet theologically informed understanding of the New Testament canon.

timeline.event: Became President of Reformed Theological Seminary, Charlotte

themes.label: New Testament Canon
themes.gloss: Kruger argues for a self-authenticating model of the New Testament canon, positing that the canonical books inherently possess divine qualities that were recognized by the early church. He critiques the historical-critical approach that views the canon as a later ecclesiastical imposition.

themes.label: Criteria of Canonicity
themes.gloss: Kruger emphasizes apostolicity, orthodoxy, and catholicity as key criteria for the recognition of canonical books, arguing against the notion that these criteria were retroactively applied by the church.

themes.label: Historical Reliability
themes.gloss: In response to critical scholars like Bart Ehrman, Kruger defends the historical reliability of the New Testament texts, asserting their early composition and consistent transmission.

name: Oliver D. Crisp
bio: Oliver D. Crisp is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian known for his rigorous engagement with systematic and philosophical theology. Born in 1972, Crisp has significantly contributed to the field through his exploration of classical Reformed doctrines, particularly those concerning Christology and the atonement. Educated at the University of Aberdeen and King's College London, Crisp has held academic positions at the University of St Andrews, Fuller Theological Seminary, and the University of Bristol. His work often dialogues with historical figures such as Jonathan Edwards and John Owen, as well as contemporary theologians like Alvin Plantinga and Richard Swinburne. Crisp is noted for his defense of the Reformed tradition while engaging critically with its tenets, particularly through his works such as 'Divinity and Humanity' and 'Retrieving Doctrine'. He has sparked discussions on topics like the nature of Christ's incarnation and the mechanics of atonement, often employing analytic philosophy to elucidate theological concepts. Crisp's contributions have been both constructive and critical, aiming to retrieve and reformulate traditional doctrines for modern contexts, making him a pivotal figure in contemporary Reformed thought.

timeline.event: Completed PhD at King's College London
Appointed at the University of St Andrews

themes.label: Christology
themes.gloss: Crisp has engaged deeply with the doctrine of the incarnation, exploring the metaphysical implications of Christ's dual nature. He defends a classical Chalcedonian Christology while addressing contemporary philosophical challenges.

themes.label: Atonement
themes.gloss: Crisp has contributed to the discourse on atonement by examining and defending the penal substitutionary model, while also considering alternative theories and their implications for Reformed theology.

themes.label: Analytic Theology
themes.gloss: Crisp is a leading figure in the analytic theology movement, employing philosophical rigor to clarify and defend theological doctrines, particularly within the Reformed tradition.

name: Tullian Tchividjian
bio: Tullian Tchividjian, a prominent figure within contemporary evangelicalism, is known for his emphasis on grace and the radical nature of the gospel. Born in 1972, Tchividjian is the grandson of the renowned evangelist Billy Graham, which positioned him within a significant evangelical lineage. His theological journey was marked by a strong focus on the doctrines of grace, heavily influenced by Reformed theology. Tchividjian's tenure as the Senior Pastor of Coral Ridge Presbyterian Church from 2009 to 2015 was pivotal, where he merged his New City Church with Coral Ridge, aiming to revitalize the congregation. His theological interlocutors include figures like Martin Luther and John Calvin, whose writings on grace and justification deeply impacted his thought. Tchividjian's work, such as 'Jesus + Nothing = Everything' (2011), underscores his belief in the sufficiency of Christ's work for salvation, challenging moralistic and legalistic tendencies within the church. However, his career faced significant controversy in 2015 when he resigned from Coral Ridge due to personal misconduct, which led to a period of reflection and restoration. Despite these challenges, Tchividjian continues to contribute to theological discourse through writing and speaking, advocating for a message centered on grace and redemption.

timeline.event: Became Senior Pastor of Coral Ridge Presbyterian Church
Resigned from Coral Ridge Presbyterian Church

themes.label: Radical Grace
themes.gloss: Tchividjian emphasizes a radical understanding of grace, arguing that the gospel is entirely about what Christ has done, not what believers do. This perspective challenges legalistic interpretations and underscores the sufficiency of Christ's atonement.

themes.label: Gospel-Centered Living
themes.gloss: He advocates for a life centered on the gospel, where believers find their identity and purpose in the finished work of Christ, rather than in personal achievements or moral performance.

themes.label: Critique of Moralism
themes.gloss: Tchividjian critiques moralism within the church, asserting that it distorts the gospel by placing undue emphasis on human effort and behavior, rather than on divine grace and forgiveness.

name: J. Todd Billings
bio: J. Todd Billings is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian whose work engages deeply with the theological implications of suffering, the sacraments, and the doctrine of union with Christ. Educated at Harvard Divinity School and Princeton Theological Seminary, Billings has contributed significantly to the discourse on Reformed theology through both his academic and pastoral roles. His interlocutors include John Calvin, Karl Barth, and contemporary theologians such as Miroslav Volf and N.T. Wright. Billings' work often addresses the intersection of systematic theology and practical ministry, particularly in the context of his personal battle with cancer, which he discusses in his book "Rejoicing in Lament: Wrestling with Incurable Cancer and Life in Christ" (2015). This work has sparked discussions on theodicy and the role of lament in Christian life. Billings is also known for his robust defense of the sacraments as means of grace, emphasizing their role in the believer's union with Christ. His book "Union with Christ: Reframing Theology and Ministry for the Church" (2011) has been influential in contemporary Reformed circles, advocating for a renewed understanding of this doctrine as central to Christian identity and mission. Billings' contributions continue to shape Reformed thought, particularly in how theology is lived out in the context of suffering and ecclesial practice.

timeline.event: Completed Ph.D. at Harvard Divinity School

themes.label: Union with Christ
themes.gloss: Billings emphasizes union with Christ as a central tenet of Reformed theology, arguing that it reframes both individual and communal Christian identity. He contends that this doctrine is not merely a theological abstraction but a lived reality that shapes ecclesial practice and personal piety.

themes.label: Theodicy and Lament
themes.gloss: In 'Rejoicing in Lament,' Billings explores the role of lament in the Christian life, particularly in the face of suffering and incurable illness. He argues for a theodicy that embraces lament as a faithful response to suffering, integrating it into the life of the church as a means of deepening trust in God's promises.

themes.label: Sacraments as Means of Grace
themes.gloss: Billings defends the sacraments as vital means of grace within the Reformed tradition, emphasizing their role in mediating the presence of Christ to the believer. He argues that the sacraments are not mere symbols but active participants in the believer's union with Christ, fostering spiritual growth and communal identity.

name: Jason S. DeRouchie
bio: Jason S. DeRouchie is a prominent contemporary evangelical theologian and biblical scholar, known for his contributions to Old Testament studies and biblical theology. He has been influential in the field through his rigorous exegesis and commitment to the authority of Scripture. DeRouchie has engaged deeply with the canonical approach, emphasizing the unity and coherence of the biblical text. His work often dialogues with figures such as John Piper and D.A. Carson, reflecting a commitment to Reformed evangelicalism. DeRouchie's scholarship is marked by a focus on the intertextuality of the Old and New Testaments, arguing for a Christocentric reading of the Hebrew Scriptures. He has been involved in controversies surrounding the hermeneutics of the Old Testament, particularly in relation to typology and the use of the Old Testament in the New Testament. His distinctive contributions include a robust defense of the continuity between the Testaments and a nuanced understanding of covenant theology. DeRouchie's publications, such as 'How to Understand and Apply the Old Testament,' have been pivotal in shaping contemporary evangelical thought on biblical interpretation. His academic career has been primarily associated with Bethlehem College & Seminary and Midwestern Baptist Theological Seminary, where he has trained a generation of pastors and scholars in a biblically faithful and theologically rich approach to Scripture.

timeline.event: Published 'How to Understand and Apply the Old Testament'
Joined Midwestern Baptist Theological Seminary faculty

themes.label: Canonical Approach
themes.gloss: DeRouchie advocates for a canonical approach to Scripture, emphasizing the unity and coherence of the biblical text across both Testaments. He argues that understanding the Bible's canonical shape is essential for proper interpretation.

themes.label: Christocentric Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: He promotes a Christocentric reading of the Old Testament, asserting that the Hebrew Scriptures find their fulfillment in Christ. This approach influences his interpretation of typology and prophecy.

themes.label: Covenant Theology
themes.gloss: DeRouchie contributes to covenant theology by exploring the continuity and discontinuity between the Old and New Covenants. He emphasizes the unfolding of God's redemptive plan through biblical covenants.

name: Jonathan Leeman
bio: Jonathan Leeman is a contemporary Baptist theologian and ecclesiologist, known for his robust articulation of church polity and authority within the context of the local church. Born in 1973, Leeman has been a prominent voice in evangelical circles, particularly through his association with 9Marks, an organization dedicated to promoting healthy church practices. His theological development has been significantly influenced by Reformed Baptist thought, with interlocutors such as Mark Dever and John Piper shaping his ecclesiological perspectives. Leeman's work often engages with the broader evangelical discourse on church governance, emphasizing the importance of congregationalism and the autonomy of the local church. His contributions to the field include a nuanced understanding of church membership and discipline, as articulated in his seminal work, 'Church Membership: How the World Knows Who Represents Jesus' (2012). Leeman has also been involved in controversies surrounding the role of authority and hierarchy in church structures, advocating for a model that balances pastoral leadership with congregational input. His distinctive contributions lie in his ability to integrate theological rigor with practical ecclesial concerns, making his work both accessible and deeply rooted in biblical exegesis.

timeline.event: Published 'Church Membership: How the World Knows Who Represents Jesus'
Published 'Don't Fire Your Church Members: The Case for Congregationalism'
Continues to serve as Editorial Director for 9Marks

themes.label: Church Polity
themes.gloss: Leeman advocates for a congregationalist model of church governance, emphasizing the autonomy of the local church and the role of the congregation in decision-making processes. His work critiques hierarchical structures and promotes a biblical model of shared authority.

themes.label: Church Membership
themes.gloss: Leeman's theology underscores the significance of formal church membership as a means of identifying the body of Christ. He argues that membership is a covenantal relationship that reflects the communal nature of the church and its witness to the world.

themes.label: Church Discipline
themes.gloss: Leeman views church discipline as an essential aspect of maintaining the purity and witness of the church. He provides a framework for understanding discipline as a loving and redemptive process aimed at restoring errant members to fellowship.

name: Marcus Peter Johnson
bio: Marcus Peter Johnson is a contemporary American theologian known for his contributions to evangelical theology, particularly in the areas of Christology and ecclesiology. Johnson's academic journey has been primarily associated with Wheaton College, where he serves as a professor of theology. His work is characterized by a robust engagement with the Reformation tradition, drawing heavily on the theological insights of figures like John Calvin and Martin Luther. Johnson's scholarship often explores the doctrine of union with Christ, a central theme in his theological oeuvre. His notable work, 'One with Christ: An Evangelical Theology of Salvation,' delves into the implications of this doctrine for understanding salvation, sanctification, and the Christian life. Johnson's interlocutors include contemporary theologians such as Michael Horton and Kevin Vanhoozer, with whom he shares a commitment to retrieving classical Protestant theology for contemporary evangelicalism. While his work is generally well-received within evangelical circles, it occasionally sparks debate over its emphasis on sacramental theology, a topic that can be contentious within broader evangelical discourse. Johnson's contributions are marked by a desire to bridge historical theology with modern ecclesial practice, advocating for a theology that is both deeply rooted in tradition and responsive to contemporary challenges.

timeline.event: Published 'One with Christ: An Evangelical Theology of Salvation'

themes.label: Union with Christ
themes.gloss: Johnson emphasizes the centrality of union with Christ in the believer's salvation, arguing that it underpins justification, sanctification, and glorification. His work seeks to retrieve this doctrine from Reformation sources, presenting it as a vital component of evangelical soteriology.

themes.label: Sacramental Theology
themes.gloss: While operating within an evangelical framework, Johnson advocates for a more sacramental understanding of Christian practices, suggesting that sacraments are means of grace that facilitate union with Christ. This stance invites dialogue and sometimes tension within evangelical circles.

themes.label: Reformation (1500 - 1599) Theology
themes.gloss: Johnson's scholarship is deeply influenced by Reformation theology, particularly the works of Calvin and Luther. He seeks to apply their insights to contemporary evangelical issues, emphasizing the relevance of historical doctrines for modern faith practice.

name: Andrew Loke
bio: Andrew Loke is a contemporary philosopher and theologian known for his work in philosophical theology and the philosophy of religion. Born in Singapore in 1974, Loke has made significant contributions to the discourse on the existence of God, the resurrection of Jesus, and the interface between science and religion. He is particularly noted for his defense of the Kalam Cosmological Argument, which he has developed in dialogue with prominent figures such as William Lane Craig and Quentin Smith. Loke's work often engages with the challenges posed by atheism and naturalism, offering robust arguments for theism. His book, 'God and Ultimate Origins,' is a seminal work that addresses the metaphysical underpinnings of cosmological arguments, advancing the discourse beyond traditional formulations. Loke has also been involved in controversies surrounding the historical reliability of the resurrection narratives, where he argues against skeptical positions by scholars like Bart Ehrman. His interdisciplinary approach, which incorporates insights from both philosophy and theology, has positioned him as a leading voice in contemporary apologetics. Loke's academic career is primarily associated with the University of Hong Kong, where he continues to influence the field through both teaching and publication.

timeline.event: Published 'Investigating the Resurrection of Jesus Christ'
Continues teaching at the University of Hong Kong

themes.label: Kalam Cosmological Argument
themes.gloss: Andrew Loke has advanced the Kalam Cosmological Argument by addressing contemporary objections and refining its premises. He engages with both classical and modern interlocutors, providing a robust defense of the argument's validity and soundness, particularly in relation to the concept of a finite past.

themes.label: Resurrection of Jesus
themes.gloss: Loke's work on the resurrection of Jesus focuses on the historical and philosophical dimensions of the event. He critiques skeptical approaches and defends the plausibility of the resurrection as a historical fact, engaging with scholars like Bart Ehrman to argue for the reliability of the Gospel accounts.

themes.label: Science and Religion
themes.gloss: In the dialogue between science and religion, Loke advocates for a complementary relationship, arguing that scientific discoveries can coexist with theological doctrines. He challenges the notion that science inherently contradicts religious belief, proposing a harmonious integration of the two fields.

name: Andrew S. Malone
bio: Andrew S. Malone is a contemporary Australian theologian known for his contributions to evangelical biblical scholarship. Educated at Ridley College, where he also serves as a faculty member, Malone has focused his academic pursuits on the intersection of biblical exegesis and systematic theology. His work often engages with the Pauline epistles, exploring the theological implications of Paul's writings for contemporary ecclesiology and soteriology. Malone's scholarship is characterized by a robust engagement with both historical-critical methodologies and evangelical hermeneutics, seeking to bridge the gap between rigorous academic inquiry and faith-based interpretation. He has contributed to discussions on the role of the Old Testament in Christian theology, advocating for a nuanced understanding of continuity and discontinuity between the Testaments. Malone's interlocutors include prominent evangelical scholars such as N.T. Wright and D.A. Carson, with whom he shares a commitment to the authority of Scripture while differing on certain hermeneutical approaches. His work has sparked discussions on the nature of biblical authority and the role of tradition in evangelical theology, positioning him as a significant voice in contemporary theological discourse.

timeline.event: Completed theological studies at Ridley College
Published significant work on Pauline theology

themes.label: Pauline Theology
themes.gloss: Malone's work on Pauline theology emphasizes the continuity between Paul's writings and the broader biblical narrative, arguing for a cohesive understanding of soteriology that integrates both Testaments.

themes.label: Biblical Authority
themes.gloss: He advocates for a high view of biblical authority, engaging with historical-critical methods while maintaining a commitment to evangelical hermeneutics.

themes.label: Old Testament Continuity
themes.gloss: Malone explores the theological continuity between the Old and New Testaments, challenging simplistic dichotomies and advocating for a nuanced understanding of biblical revelation.

name: Christopher R.J. Holmes
bio: Christopher R.J. Holmes is a contemporary Reformed theologian known for his rigorous engagement with classical theological sources and his contributions to the doctrine of God. Holmes has been a prominent voice in the retrieval of patristic and medieval insights for contemporary theology, particularly through his work on the divine attributes and the doctrine of the Trinity. He has engaged deeply with figures such as Thomas Aquinas, Karl Barth, and Augustine, seeking to bridge historical theology with modern concerns. Holmes's work often centers on the intersection of dogmatics and spirituality, emphasizing the formative role of doctrine in the Christian life. His significant publications include 'The Lord is Good: Seeking the God of the Psalter' and 'A Theology of the Christian Life: Imitating and Participating in God'. Holmes's theological method is marked by a commitment to the primacy of Scripture, interpreted within the context of the Church's historic creeds and confessions. He has been involved in various theological controversies, particularly around the nature of divine simplicity and the communicable attributes of God, advocating for a nuanced understanding that respects both divine transcendence and immanence. Holmes's contributions continue to shape contemporary discussions on the coherence and relevance of classical theism in a postmodern context.

timeline.event: Published 'A Theology of the Christian Life'

themes.label: Divine Attributes
themes.gloss: Holmes explores the classical doctrine of divine simplicity, arguing for its continued relevance in contemporary theology. He emphasizes the communicable attributes of God, such as goodness and love, as essential for understanding divine-human relations.

themes.label: Doctrine of the Trinity
themes.gloss: Holmes engages with patristic and medieval sources to articulate a robust Trinitarian theology. He stresses the importance of the relational dynamics within the Godhead as foundational for Christian life and worship.

themes.label: Scripture and Tradition
themes.gloss: Holmes advocates for a hermeneutical approach that prioritizes Scripture while being deeply informed by the Church's creeds and confessions. He argues that this approach provides a stable framework for doctrinal development and spiritual formation.

name: Grant Macaskill
bio: Grant Macaskill is a prominent contemporary theologian specializing in New Testament studies and the intersection of theology and disability. Born in 1974, Macaskill has significantly contributed to the theological understanding of the New Testament's ethical and eschatological dimensions. He holds the Kirby Laing Chair of New Testament Exegesis at the University of Aberdeen, where he has been influential in advancing scholarly discourse on the Pauline epistles and the theological implications of early Christian texts. His work often engages with the writings of N.T. Wright and Richard Bauckham, situating his scholarship within a broader conversation about the historical and theological contexts of the New Testament. Macaskill's distinctive contribution lies in his exploration of the concept of 'union with Christ,' which he examines through the lens of Second Temple Judaism and early Christian thought. His book 'Union with Christ in the New Testament' is a seminal work that has sparked discussions on the ontological and ethical implications of this doctrine. Additionally, Macaskill has been a leading voice in integrating disability studies with biblical theology, challenging traditional interpretations and advocating for a more inclusive theological framework. His interdisciplinary approach has not been without controversy, as it pushes the boundaries of conventional exegesis and invites dialogue across diverse theological traditions.

timeline.event: Appointed Kirby Laing Chair of New Testament Exegesis at University of Aberdeen
Published 'Union with Christ in the New Testament'
Published significant work on theology and disability

themes.label: Union with Christ
themes.gloss: Macaskill explores 'union with Christ' as a central theme in Pauline theology, emphasizing its ontological and ethical dimensions. He argues that this union is not merely metaphorical but involves a participatory reality that shapes Christian identity and ethics.

themes.label: Theology and Disability
themes.gloss: Macaskill integrates disability studies into biblical theology, advocating for a hermeneutic that recognizes the dignity and agency of disabled individuals. He challenges traditional interpretations that marginalize or overlook the experiences of disabled persons in theological discourse.

themes.label: Second Temple Judaism
themes.gloss: Macaskill situates New Testament texts within the context of Second Temple Judaism, arguing that understanding this historical backdrop is crucial for interpreting early Christian writings. His work highlights the continuity and divergence between Jewish and Christian eschatological expectations.

name: James E. Dolezal
bio: James E. Dolezal is a contemporary Reformed theologian known for his rigorous defense of classical theism, particularly the doctrines of divine simplicity and immutability. Educated at The Master's Seminary and Westminster Theological Seminary, Dolezal has become a prominent voice in the ongoing discourse on the nature of God within Reformed circles. His seminal work, 'All That Is in God' (2017), critiques modern theological trends that, in his view, compromise the classical understanding of God's nature by introducing concepts of divine change and passibility. Dolezal's interlocutors include theologians like Bruce Ware and John Frame, whom he challenges for their perceived deviations from classical theism. His arguments are deeply rooted in the scholastic tradition, drawing heavily on the works of Thomas Aquinas and the Reformed scholastics. Dolezal's contributions are not without controversy; his staunch adherence to classical theism has sparked debates regarding the coherence and applicability of these doctrines in contemporary theology. Despite the controversies, Dolezal's work continues to influence discussions on divine attributes, offering a robust defense of a God who is wholly other, immutable, and simple.

timeline.event: Completed Ph.D. at Westminster Theological Seminary

themes.label: Divine Simplicity
themes.gloss: Dolezal argues for a robust understanding of divine simplicity, asserting that God is not composed of parts and that His attributes are identical with His essence. He critiques contemporary theologians who, in his view, undermine this doctrine by suggesting that God has distinct, separable attributes.

themes.label: Divine Immutability
themes.gloss: Dolezal defends the classical doctrine of divine immutability, maintaining that God does not undergo change. He challenges modern theological perspectives that propose God can change in response to creation, arguing that such views compromise the traditional understanding of God's perfection.

themes.label: Critique of Theistic Personalism
themes.gloss: Dolezal critiques theistic personalism, which posits a more relational and mutable conception of God. He argues that this view diminishes the transcendence and aseity of God, advocating instead for a return to classical theism's emphasis on God's absolute otherness and independence.

name: Michael Bird
bio: Michael Bird is an Australian theologian renowned for his contributions to New Testament studies and evangelical theology. Born in 1974, Bird has become a prominent voice in contemporary theological discourse, particularly within the evangelical tradition. He is a prolific author, with works such as 'Evangelical Theology: A Biblical and Systematic Introduction' and 'The New Testament in Its World,' co-authored with N.T. Wright, which have significantly influenced evangelical scholarship. Bird's theological development is marked by a robust engagement with both historical-critical methods and a commitment to the authority of Scripture. His interlocutors include figures like N.T. Wright, with whom he shares a focus on the historical Jesus and Pauline studies, and John Dominic Crossan, whose historical Jesus research Bird critically engages. Bird has been involved in controversies surrounding the nature of evangelical identity, advocating for a more inclusive and globally aware evangelicalism. His distinctive contributions include a nuanced understanding of the relationship between the Old and New Testaments and a defense of the historical reliability of the Gospels. Bird's work is characterized by a commitment to bridging the gap between academic scholarship and church praxis, making him a pivotal figure in contemporary evangelical thought.

timeline.event: Published 'Evangelical Theology: A Biblical and Systematic Introduction'
Co-authored 'The New Testament in Its World' with N.T. Wright

themes.label: Evangelical Identity
themes.gloss: Bird advocates for a broad and inclusive evangelical identity that is globally aware and engages critically with contemporary issues while maintaining a commitment to biblical authority.

themes.label: Historical Jesus
themes.gloss: Bird engages with historical-critical methods to affirm the historical reliability of the Gospels, often dialoguing with scholars like N.T. Wright and critiquing others such as John Dominic Crossan.

themes.label: Pauline Studies
themes.gloss: Bird's work in Pauline theology emphasizes the continuity between Paul's writings and the broader biblical narrative, challenging traditional Lutheran readings and advocating for a 'New Perspective' approach.

name: Scott Swain
bio: Scott Swain is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian known for his contributions to systematic theology and his engagement with classical theism. Swain's theological development is deeply rooted in the Reformed tradition, drawing heavily on the works of John Calvin and the Reformed scholastics. He has been a significant voice in the retrieval of classical doctrines of God, particularly in the context of modern theological debates. Swain's interlocutors include theologians such as Richard Muller and Michael Allen, with whom he has collaborated extensively. His work often addresses controversies surrounding the doctrine of the Trinity, divine simplicity, and the nature of revelation. Swain's distinctive contributions include a robust defense of the classical doctrine of God, emphasizing the importance of divine simplicity and immutability in contemporary theological discourse. His scholarly output includes numerous articles and books, such as 'Reformed Catholicity' co-authored with Michael Allen, which argues for a catholic and ecumenical approach within the Reformed tradition. Swain's work is characterized by a commitment to the authority of Scripture and the confessions of the Reformed churches, seeking to articulate a theology that is both faithful to the tradition and responsive to contemporary challenges.

timeline.event: Appointed President of Reformed Theological Seminary, Orlando

themes.label: Doctrine of the Trinity
themes.gloss: Swain emphasizes the classical understanding of the Trinity, advocating for a return to Nicene orthodoxy. He argues against modern revisions that compromise the unity and simplicity of God, stressing the importance of eternal generation and the consubstantiality of the persons.

themes.label: Divine Simplicity
themes.gloss: Swain defends the doctrine of divine simplicity as essential to a coherent doctrine of God. He critiques contemporary theological trends that reject simplicity, arguing that it safeguards the unity and aseity of God, ensuring that God's attributes are not composite.

themes.label: Revelation and Scripture
themes.gloss: Swain upholds the authority and sufficiency of Scripture, engaging with historical-critical methods while maintaining a high view of biblical inspiration. He explores the relationship between Scripture and tradition, advocating for a hermeneutic that respects both.

name: Simon J. Gathercole
bio: Simon J. Gathercole is a prominent British New Testament scholar and theologian, known for his contributions to Pauline studies and early Christian literature. Born in 1974, Gathercole has established himself as a leading figure in contemporary evangelical scholarship. He is a Reader in New Testament Studies at the University of Cambridge and a Fellow of Fitzwilliam College. Gathercole's work is characterized by a rigorous historical-critical approach, often engaging with the New Perspective on Paul, a movement that re-evaluates the apostle's writings in light of Second Temple Judaism. His critical engagement with scholars such as E.P. Sanders and N.T. Wright has been pivotal in shaping contemporary debates on Pauline theology. Gathercole's book, 'Where is Boasting? Early Jewish Soteriology and Paul's Response in Romans 1â€“5,' challenges prevailing interpretations of Pauline soteriology, arguing for a more nuanced understanding of justification and works. Additionally, his research on apocryphal gospels, particularly the Gospel of Thomas, has contributed significantly to the understanding of early Christian diversity. Gathercole's scholarship is marked by a commitment to integrating rigorous exegesis with theological reflection, making substantial contributions to both academic and ecclesial contexts.

timeline.event: Published 'The Composition of the Gospel of Thomas'

themes.label: Pauline Soteriology
themes.gloss: Gathercole critiques the New Perspective on Paul, emphasizing a traditional understanding of justification by faith while acknowledging the role of works in Paul's theology.

themes.label: Apocryphal Gospels
themes.gloss: His analysis of texts like the Gospel of Thomas highlights the diversity of early Christian thought and challenges the canonical boundaries of early Christian literature.

themes.label: Second Temple Judaism
themes.gloss: Gathercole's work situates Pauline theology within the broader context of Second Temple Jewish beliefs, offering a nuanced perspective on Jewish soteriological concepts.

name: Alan S. Bandy
bio: Alan S. Bandy is a contemporary American theologian and biblical scholar, primarily known for his work in New Testament studies with a focus on apocalyptic literature. Bandy's academic journey began with a strong foundation in evangelical theology, which he further developed through rigorous scholarship. He earned his Ph.D. from Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary, where his dissertation explored the use of Old Testament imagery in the Book of Revelation. Bandy's interlocutors include notable scholars such as Richard Bauckham and G.K. Beale, with whom he shares a commitment to understanding the New Testament within its first-century Jewish context. His work often engages with the theological implications of eschatology, particularly how apocalyptic texts inform contemporary Christian praxis. Bandy has contributed significantly to the field through his publications, including 'The Prophetic Lawsuit in the Book of Revelation,' which examines the legal metaphor in Revelation as a critique of Roman imperial power. His scholarship is characterized by a methodological rigor that combines historical-critical analysis with theological reflection. Bandy has also been involved in various controversies, particularly regarding the interpretation of apocalyptic literature in light of modern evangelical eschatology. His distinctive contributions lie in his ability to bridge the gap between academic scholarship and ecclesial application, making complex theological concepts accessible to a broader audience. As a professor at Oklahoma Baptist University, Bandy continues to influence a new generation of theologians and biblical scholars.

timeline.event: Completed Ph.D. at Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary
Published 'The Prophetic Lawsuit in the Book of Revelation'
Joined faculty at Oklahoma Baptist University

themes.label: Apocalyptic Literature
themes.gloss: Bandy's work on apocalyptic literature, particularly the Book of Revelation, emphasizes the use of Old Testament imagery and its implications for understanding early Christian eschatology. He argues for a reading that considers the socio-political context of the first century, challenging contemporary evangelical interpretations that often overlook historical nuances.

themes.label: Eschatology
themes.gloss: Bandy's eschatological studies focus on the theological and practical implications of apocalyptic texts. He critiques popular evangelical eschatologies that prioritize speculative futurism over the ethical demands of the present, advocating for a more nuanced understanding that integrates historical context with theological reflection.

themes.label: Roman Imperial Critique
themes.gloss: In his analysis of Revelation, Bandy highlights the text's critique of Roman imperial ideology. He explores how the apocalyptic imagery serves as a prophetic lawsuit against the empire, offering a theological framework for understanding the early Christian resistance to imperial power and its relevance for contemporary socio-political issues.

name: Brant Pitre
bio: Brant Pitre is a contemporary Catholic theologian renowned for his contributions to biblical theology and Christology. Born in 1975, Pitre has become a prominent figure in Catholic scholarship, particularly known for his work on the Jewish roots of Christianity. He earned his Ph.D. in New Testament and ancient Judaism from the University of Notre Dame, where he studied under the guidance of John P. Meier, a leading historical Jesus scholar. Pitre's scholarship often engages with the historical-critical method, yet he seeks to integrate this with a robust theological interpretation that is faithful to Catholic tradition. His notable works include 'Jesus and the Jewish Roots of the Eucharist' and 'The Case for Jesus,' where he argues against the skepticism of modern biblical criticism regarding the historical reliability of the Gospels. Pitre's interlocutors include N.T. Wright and Richard Bauckham, with whom he shares a commitment to understanding Jesus within his first-century Jewish context. Controversially, Pitre challenges the late dating of the Gospels, positing an earlier composition that aligns with traditional Catholic views. His work has been influential in apologetic circles, providing a bridge between academic scholarship and lay Catholic education.

timeline.event: Completed Ph.D. at University of Notre Dame
Published 'Jesus and the Jewish Roots of the Eucharist'

themes.label: Jewish Roots of Christianity
themes.gloss: Pitre emphasizes the continuity between Judaism and Christianity, arguing that understanding Jesus' Jewish context is crucial for interpreting the New Testament. He explores how Jewish traditions and scriptures inform Christian sacraments and doctrines, particularly the Eucharist.

themes.label: Historical Reliability of the Gospels
themes.gloss: Pitre defends the historical reliability of the Gospels against modern critical skepticism. He argues for an earlier dating of the texts and emphasizes their coherence with Jewish customs and beliefs of the first century.

themes.label: Christology
themes.gloss: Pitre's Christological work focuses on affirming the divinity of Jesus through scriptural exegesis. He engages with both historical and theological dimensions, challenging contemporary views that separate the Jesus of history from the Christ of faith.

name: Bruce Riley Ashford
bio: Bruce Riley Ashford is a prominent contemporary evangelical theologian known for his contributions to public theology and the integration of faith and culture. Born in 1975, Ashford has been a significant figure in evangelical circles, particularly through his work at Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary, where he has served in various capacities, including Provost and Dean of Faculty. His theological development has been influenced by Reformed and evangelical traditions, with interlocutors such as Abraham Kuyper and Lesslie Newbigin shaping his thought. Ashford's work often engages with the intersection of theology and public life, advocating for a robust Christian witness in the public square. He has been involved in controversies surrounding the role of Christianity in politics, emphasizing a balanced approach that avoids both withdrawal and over-identification with political ideologies. His distinctive contributions include a focus on the cultural mandate and the lordship of Christ over all areas of life, as articulated in works like 'Every Square Inch: An Introduction to Cultural Engagement for Christians.' Ashford's writings address the challenges of secularism and pluralism, urging Christians to engage culture thoughtfully and faithfully. His approach is characterized by a commitment to biblical authority and a desire to articulate a coherent Christian worldview that speaks to contemporary issues.

timeline.event: Joined Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary faculty
Appointed Provost of Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary

themes.label: Public Theology
themes.gloss: Ashford emphasizes the importance of Christian engagement in public life, advocating for a theology that informs and transforms societal structures. He draws on Kuyperian thought to argue for the lordship of Christ over all spheres of life, urging Christians to participate actively in cultural and political arenas.

themes.label: Cultural Engagement
themes.gloss: Ashford's approach to cultural engagement is rooted in the belief that Christians are called to influence culture through faithful presence. He critiques both cultural withdrawal and uncritical assimilation, proposing a model that seeks to redeem and renew culture in light of the gospel.

themes.label: Theology and Politics
themes.gloss: In his exploration of the relationship between theology and politics, Ashford navigates the complexities of Christian political involvement. He advocates for a principled engagement that respects the autonomy of the political sphere while affirming the moral and ethical implications of the Christian faith.

name: Christopher Zoccali
bio: Christopher Zoccali is a contemporary American theologian known for his contributions to Pauline studies and New Testament exegesis. He has engaged deeply with the works of N.T. Wright and James D.G. Dunn, particularly in the context of the New Perspective on Paul. Zoccali's scholarship often explores the intersection of Second Temple Judaism and early Christianity, emphasizing the socio-historical context of Pauline theology. His critical engagement with the Apostle Paul's writings has led to a nuanced understanding of justification, law, and grace, challenging traditional evangelical interpretations. Zoccali has also contributed to discussions on the role of the Gentiles in the early church, advocating for a more inclusive understanding of Paul's mission. His work is characterized by a rigorous application of historical-critical methods, aiming to bridge the gap between academic scholarship and ecclesial application. Zoccali's publications, including his notable work 'Reading Philippians after Supersessionism,' reflect his commitment to addressing contemporary theological issues through a robust exegetical framework. His teaching at Northeastern Seminary has influenced a generation of students, encouraging them to engage critically with biblical texts while remaining rooted in evangelical tradition.

timeline.event: Completed PhD in New Testament Studies

themes.label: Pauline Theology
themes.gloss: Zoccali's work in Pauline theology emphasizes the socio-historical context of Paul's letters, particularly focusing on the implications of the New Perspective on Paul. He argues for a reading of Paul that considers the Jewish roots of his theology and the implications for understanding justification and the law.

themes.label: Second Temple Judaism
themes.gloss: Zoccali engages with Second Temple Jewish literature to illuminate the background of early Christian texts. His scholarship highlights the continuity and discontinuity between Jewish and Christian thought, particularly in the writings of Paul.

themes.label: Historical-Critical Exegesis
themes.gloss: Zoccali employs historical-critical methods to interpret New Testament texts, advocating for a reading that is both academically rigorous and theologically relevant. His approach seeks to uncover the original meaning of the texts while addressing contemporary theological questions.

name: Heath A. Thomas
bio: Heath A. Thomas is a contemporary evangelical theologian known for his contributions to biblical theology and hermeneutics. Born in 1975, Thomas has established himself as a significant voice in the field of Old Testament studies. He serves as the President of Oklahoma Baptist University, where he also holds a professorship in Old Testament and Biblical Theology. Thomas's scholarly work often engages with the theological interpretation of Scripture, emphasizing the narrative and theological coherence of the biblical canon. His interlocutors include scholars such as Walter Brueggemann and N.T. Wright, with whom he shares a commitment to the theological and pastoral application of biblical texts. Thomas has contributed to the discourse on the prophetic literature of the Old Testament, particularly focusing on the book of Lamentations, where he explores themes of suffering, divine justice, and hope. His work is characterized by a robust evangelical hermeneutic that seeks to bridge the gap between ancient texts and contemporary faith communities. Thomas's distinctive contribution lies in his ability to integrate rigorous academic scholarship with a deep commitment to the life of the church, making his work accessible and relevant to both scholars and laypersons alike.

timeline.event: Completed Ph.D. in Old Testament Studies
Appointed President of Oklahoma Baptist University

themes.label: Theological Interpretation of Scripture
themes.gloss: Thomas advocates for a hermeneutic that emphasizes the narrative and theological unity of the biblical canon, engaging with contemporary issues through a lens of evangelical theology.

themes.label: Prophetic Literature
themes.gloss: His work on the prophetic books, especially Lamentations, delves into themes of suffering and divine justice, offering a theological framework for understanding these texts in light of modern challenges.

themes.label: Biblical Theology
themes.gloss: Thomas contributes to the field by integrating biblical theology with pastoral concerns, aiming to make scholarly insights accessible to the church community.

name: James M. Hamilton Jr.
bio: James M. Hamilton Jr. is a contemporary American theologian known for his contributions to evangelical biblical theology. Born in 1975, Hamilton has established himself as a prominent figure in the field of biblical studies, particularly through his work on the narrative and theological coherence of the Bible. He serves as a professor of biblical theology at the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, where his teaching and writing emphasize the centrality of Christ in the biblical canon. Hamilton's interlocutors include scholars like D.A. Carson and Thomas Schreiner, with whom he shares a commitment to a high view of Scripture and a Christocentric hermeneutic. His major works, such as 'God's Glory in Salvation through Judgment' (2010), argue for a thematic unity in the Bible centered on God's glory manifested through acts of salvation and judgment. Hamilton has engaged in controversies surrounding the interpretation of biblical texts, particularly in relation to eschatology and the role of typology in understanding the Old Testament. His distinctive contributions include a robust defense of biblical inerrancy and a narrative approach to theology that seeks to integrate biblical exegesis with systematic theology. Hamilton's work continues to influence evangelical thought, particularly in the areas of biblical theology and hermeneutics.

timeline.event: Published 'God's Glory in Salvation through Judgment'
Became Professor of Biblical Theology at Southern Baptist Theological Seminary

themes.label: Biblical Theology
themes.gloss: Hamilton emphasizes the narrative and theological coherence of the Bible, arguing for a Christocentric reading that highlights God's glory in salvation through judgment.

themes.label: Inerrancy
themes.gloss: Hamilton is a staunch defender of biblical inerrancy, maintaining that the Scriptures are without error in all their teachings and are authoritative for faith and practice.

themes.label: Typology
themes.gloss: He advocates for a typological reading of the Old Testament, seeing events, persons, and institutions as foreshadowing Christ and the New Covenant.

name: Kirk R. MacGregor
bio: Kirk R. MacGregor is a contemporary American theologian known for his contributions to evangelical theology, particularly in the areas of Molinism and the historical Jesus. MacGregor's academic journey began at the University of Illinois, where he developed a keen interest in the intersection of philosophy and theology. His work often engages with the thought of Luis de Molina, a 16th-century Jesuit theologian, whose concept of middle knowledge MacGregor has vigorously defended and expanded upon. MacGregor's interlocutors include both classical figures like Molina and contemporary scholars such as William Lane Craig, with whom he shares a commitment to the compatibility of divine foreknowledge and human free will. His book, 'A Molinist-Anabaptist Systematic Theology,' exemplifies his innovative approach, integrating Molinist concepts with Anabaptist ecclesiology. MacGregor has also contributed to the historical Jesus debate, arguing for the historical reliability of the Gospel accounts. His work has sparked discussions and some controversies, particularly among Reformed theologians who challenge his views on divine sovereignty. Despite these debates, MacGregor remains a prominent voice in evangelical circles, advocating for a theology that is both intellectually rigorous and pastorally relevant.

timeline.event: Published first major work on Molinism

themes.label: Molinism
themes.gloss: MacGregor defends and expands upon Luis de Molina's concept of middle knowledge, arguing for its compatibility with evangelical theology and its utility in resolving issues of divine foreknowledge and human freedom.

themes.label: Historical Jesus
themes.gloss: MacGregor engages in the historical Jesus debate, advocating for the historical reliability of the Gospel accounts and emphasizing their theological significance.

themes.label: Anabaptist Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: Incorporating Anabaptist principles, MacGregor's theology emphasizes a community-oriented ecclesiology that aligns with his Molinist framework, advocating for a church that is both theologically robust and socially engaged.

name: Adonis Vidu
bio: Adonis Vidu is a contemporary Romanian theologian known for his contributions to systematic theology, particularly in the areas of Trinitarian theology and the doctrine of atonement. Educated in both Romania and the United States, Vidu has engaged deeply with the Reformed tradition while also drawing on Eastern Orthodox and patristic sources. His work often dialogues with classical theological figures such as Augustine and Aquinas, as well as modern theologians like Karl Barth and T.F. Torrance. Vidu's book 'Atonement, Law, and Justice: The Cross in Historical and Cultural Contexts' explores the multifaceted nature of atonement theories, arguing for a nuanced understanding that incorporates legal and relational dimensions. He has also contributed significantly to discussions on the doctrine of the Trinity, emphasizing the importance of maintaining both unity and distinction within the Godhead. Vidu's scholarship is characterized by a commitment to theological precision and a desire to bridge historical doctrines with contemporary issues. His work often addresses controversies surrounding the interpretation of classical doctrines in modern contexts, advocating for a retrieval of traditional insights to inform current theological debates.

timeline.event: Completed Ph.D. at University of Nottingham

themes.label: Trinitarian Theology
themes.gloss: Vidu emphasizes the balance between unity and distinction within the Trinity, engaging with both patristic sources and contemporary debates to argue for a robust understanding of Trinitarian relations.

themes.label: Doctrine of Atonement
themes.gloss: In 'Atonement, Law, and Justice,' Vidu explores the legal and relational aspects of atonement, advocating for a comprehensive view that integrates historical and cultural contexts.

themes.label: Engagement with Patristic Thought
themes.gloss: Vidu frequently draws on patristic sources, particularly Augustine, to inform his contemporary theological work, seeking to retrieve classical insights for modern application.

name: Tom Greggs
bio: Tom Greggs is a prominent British theologian known for his contributions to contemporary evangelical theology. Born in 1976, Greggs has established himself as a leading voice in systematic theology, particularly through his work on the doctrine of salvation and ecclesiology. His academic journey began at the University of Oxford, where he completed his DPhil, focusing on Karl Barth, a theologian whose influence is evident throughout Greggs' work. Greggs' engagement with Barthian theology is nuanced, often seeking to bridge Barth's insights with contemporary evangelical concerns. His book, 'Theology Against Religion: Constructive Dialogues with Bonhoeffer and Barth,' exemplifies his commitment to dialogue between historical theological figures and modern issues. Greggs has also been involved in ecumenical discussions, advocating for a theology that transcends denominational boundaries. His work often addresses the interplay between theology and public life, emphasizing the role of the church in societal transformation. As a professor at the University of Aberdeen, Greggs has been instrumental in shaping the next generation of theologians, fostering an environment that encourages critical engagement with both classical and contemporary theological issues.

timeline.event: Completed DPhil at University of Oxford
Appointed Professor at University of Aberdeen

themes.label: Doctrine of Salvation
themes.gloss: Greggs' approach to soteriology is characterized by an emphasis on universal salvation, drawing from Barthian theology while engaging with contemporary evangelical perspectives. He argues for a Christocentric understanding of salvation that is inclusive yet rooted in traditional doctrinal frameworks.

themes.label: Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: In his ecclesiological work, Greggs advocates for a church that is both theologically grounded and socially engaged. He emphasizes the church's role in public life, arguing for a model of ecclesial existence that is transformative and reflective of the gospel's social implications.

themes.label: Theology and Public Life
themes.gloss: Greggs explores the intersection of theology and public life, arguing for a robust engagement of theological discourse with societal issues. He posits that theology should not be confined to academic or ecclesial settings but should actively contribute to public debates and societal transformation.

name: Andrew J. Byers
bio: Andrew J. Byers is a contemporary theologian whose work primarily engages with the intersection of biblical studies and ecclesiology within the evangelical tradition. Byers has contributed significantly to the understanding of the New Testament's narrative framework, particularly through his exploration of the Johannine literature. His academic journey began with a focus on the narrative dynamics of the Fourth Gospel, which he examined in his seminal work, 'Ecclesiology and Theosis in the Gospel of John'. Byers' scholarship is marked by a dialogical engagement with both historical-critical methodologies and contemporary theological discourse, positioning him as a bridge between traditional exegesis and modern ecclesiological concerns. His interlocutors include prominent figures such as Richard Bauckham and N.T. Wright, whose works on early Christian identity and eschatology have influenced Byers' own theological trajectory. A distinctive feature of Byers' contribution is his emphasis on the communal and transformative aspects of scriptural interpretation, advocating for a reading of the New Testament that is both theologically robust and ecclesially relevant. Byers has also been involved in various academic and ecclesial controversies, particularly those surrounding the role of narrative theology in evangelical contexts, where he argues for a more nuanced understanding of biblical authority that incorporates narrative and theological dimensions. His work continues to shape contemporary evangelical thought, particularly in the areas of ecclesiology and biblical hermeneutics.

timeline.event: Completed PhD at University of Durham
Published 'Ecclesiology and Theosis in the Gospel of John'
Joined Cambridge University as a lecturer

themes.label: Narrative Theology
themes.gloss: Byers emphasizes the narrative structure of the New Testament, particularly the Gospel of John, arguing for its centrality in understanding early Christian identity and theology.

themes.label: Ecclesiology
themes.gloss: He explores the communal implications of biblical texts, advocating for an ecclesiology that is informed by narrative theology and the transformative potential of scriptural engagement.

themes.label: Theosis
themes.gloss: Byers integrates the concept of theosis into his reading of the Johannine literature, suggesting that the Gospel of John presents a vision of divine participation that is both communal and eschatological.

name: Daniel Castelo
bio: Daniel Castelo is a contemporary theologian known for his contributions to Pentecostal and Wesleyan theology. Born in 1977, Castelo has been a prominent voice in theological circles, particularly in the dialogue between Pentecostalism and the broader Christian tradition. His work often engages with the theological insights of John Wesley, emphasizing the experiential and transformative aspects of faith. Castelo's scholarship is marked by a robust engagement with the doctrine of the Holy Spirit, where he seeks to bridge the gap between classical Pentecostalism and more traditional theological frameworks. His notable works include 'Pentecostalism as a Christian Mystical Tradition' and 'Theological Theodicy'. Castelo has been involved in discussions on the nature of divine action and the problem of evil, often critiquing overly rationalistic approaches in favor of a more narrative and relational understanding of God's interaction with the world. He has also contributed to the development of a Wesleyan-Pentecostal hermeneutic, advocating for a reading of Scripture that is both Spirit-led and contextually aware. His academic career is primarily associated with Seattle Pacific University, where he has influenced a generation of students and scholars through his teaching and writing.

timeline.event: Joined faculty at Seattle Pacific University
Published 'Pentecostalism as a Christian Mystical Tradition'

themes.label: Pentecostal Mysticism
themes.gloss: Castelo argues for understanding Pentecostalism as a form of Christian mysticism, emphasizing the experiential and transformative aspects of the faith. He seeks to integrate Pentecostal spirituality with broader Christian mystical traditions, highlighting the role of the Holy Spirit in personal and communal transformation.

themes.label: Theodicy
themes.gloss: In 'Theological Theodicy', Castelo critiques traditional theodicies for their rationalistic tendencies, proposing instead a narrative approach that emphasizes God's relational presence in the midst of suffering. He argues for a theodicy that is deeply rooted in the Christian narrative and the lived experience of believers.

themes.label: Wesleyan-Pentecostal Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Castelo advocates for a hermeneutic approach that combines Wesleyan and Pentecostal insights, emphasizing a Spirit-led reading of Scripture that is attentive to historical and cultural contexts. This approach seeks to balance the authority of Scripture with the dynamic work of the Holy Spirit in interpretation.

name: Keith L. Johnson
bio: Keith L. Johnson is a contemporary American theologian known for his contributions to evangelical theology, particularly in the areas of systematic theology and the doctrine of the Trinity. Educated at Wheaton College, where he also serves as a faculty member, Johnson has engaged deeply with the works of Karl Barth, seeking to bridge Barthian insights with evangelical commitments. His scholarly endeavors often focus on the intersection of classical theological doctrines and contemporary issues, aiming to articulate a coherent evangelical theology that remains faithful to historical orthodoxy while addressing modern challenges. Johnson's work is marked by a rigorous engagement with patristic sources, especially in his exploration of the Trinity, where he emphasizes the relational aspects of the Godhead in dialogue with both Eastern and Western traditions. He has also contributed to discussions on the nature of revelation and the authority of Scripture, advocating for a nuanced understanding that respects both the divine and human elements of biblical texts. Through his writings and teachings, Johnson has become a significant voice in evangelical circles, known for his ability to navigate complex theological landscapes with clarity and depth.

timeline.event: Published significant work on Karl Barth

themes.label: Doctrine of the Trinity
themes.gloss: Johnson emphasizes the relational aspects of the Trinity, engaging with both Eastern and Western theological traditions to articulate a robust evangelical understanding.

themes.label: Karl Barth and Evangelical Theology
themes.gloss: He explores the integration of Barthian insights into evangelical theology, particularly focusing on the doctrines of revelation and Scripture.

themes.label: Systematic Theology
themes.gloss: Johnson contributes to systematic theology by addressing contemporary issues through the lens of classical doctrines, maintaining fidelity to historical orthodoxy.

name: Kevin DeYoung
bio: Kevin DeYoung is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian and pastor known for his robust defense of traditional evangelical doctrines and his engagement with modern cultural issues. Born in 1977, DeYoung has emerged as a leading voice within the Reformed tradition, particularly through his pastoral work and prolific writing. He serves as the senior pastor at Christ Covenant Church in Matthews, North Carolina, and has been a member of the Gospel Coalition's Council. DeYoung's theological development has been significantly influenced by figures such as John Calvin and Jonathan Edwards, as well as modern Reformed theologians like J.I. Packer and John Piper. His works, including 'The Hole in Our Holiness' (2012) and 'Taking God at His Word' (2014), emphasize the authority of Scripture and the necessity of personal holiness. DeYoung has been involved in controversies surrounding the role of women in ministry, the nature of sanctification, and the church's response to cultural shifts, often advocating for a conservative stance. His interlocutors include both allies within the Reformed community and critics from more progressive theological circles. DeYoung's distinctive contributions lie in his ability to articulate complex theological concepts in accessible language, his commitment to biblical inerrancy, and his emphasis on the importance of doctrinal clarity in the life of the church.

themes.label: Biblical Inerrancy
themes.gloss: DeYoung staunchly defends the inerrancy of Scripture, arguing that the Bible is without error in all its teachings. He emphasizes the necessity of upholding this doctrine for maintaining theological orthodoxy and the authority of Christian teaching.

themes.label: Sanctification
themes.gloss: In his writings, DeYoung stresses the importance of sanctification as a process of becoming more like Christ. He critiques both antinomianism and legalism, advocating for a balanced view that recognizes the role of grace and effort in the believer's growth in holiness.

themes.label: Cultural Engagement
themes.gloss: DeYoung engages with contemporary cultural issues from a conservative Reformed perspective, addressing topics such as gender roles, sexuality, and religious liberty. He calls for the church to remain faithful to biblical teachings while engaging the culture with truth and grace.

name: Paul T. Nimmo
bio: Paul T. Nimmo is a prominent contemporary Reformed theologian known for his rigorous engagement with the works of Karl Barth and his contributions to systematic theology. Born in 1977, Nimmo has established himself as a leading scholar in the field of Reformed theology, particularly through his exploration of Barthian thought. His academic journey has been marked by significant positions at the University of Aberdeen and the University of Edinburgh, where he has influenced a generation of students and scholars. Nimmo's work often dialogues with classical Reformed theologians, while also engaging with contemporary theological debates. His book 'Being in Action: The Theological Shape of Barth's Ethical Vision' is a critical examination of Barth's ethics, offering a nuanced understanding of the interplay between divine command and human action. Nimmo's scholarship is characterized by a commitment to the coherence of doctrine and ethics, emphasizing the practical implications of theological concepts. He has also contributed to the understanding of the doctrine of the Trinity, exploring its implications for ecclesiology and ethics. Nimmo's work is marked by a careful balance of historical fidelity and contemporary relevance, making him a significant voice in modern Reformed theology.

timeline.event: Published 'Being in Action: The Theological Shape of Barth's Ethical Vision'
Appointed to the University of Aberdeen

themes.label: Barthian Ethics
themes.gloss: Nimmo's exploration of Karl Barth's ethical framework emphasizes the dynamic relationship between divine command and human action. He argues for a nuanced understanding of Barth's ethics, highlighting the centrality of Christology in ethical deliberation and the transformative potential of divine grace in human decision-making.

themes.label: Doctrine of the Trinity
themes.gloss: Nimmo's work on the Trinity examines its ecclesiological and ethical implications, arguing for a model of community and relationality that reflects the triune nature of God. He emphasizes the practical outworking of Trinitarian theology in the life of the church and its mission in the world.

themes.label: Systematic Theology
themes.gloss: Nimmo contributes to systematic theology by integrating classical Reformed doctrines with contemporary issues, maintaining a balance between doctrinal coherence and practical application. His work often addresses the intersection of theology and ethics, advocating for a holistic approach to theological inquiry.

name: S. Joshua Swamidass
bio: S. Joshua Swamidass is a contemporary theologian and scientist whose work bridges the domains of evolutionary biology and evangelical theology. As an associate professor at Washington University in St. Louis, Swamidass has made significant contributions to the dialogue between science and religion, particularly through his book 'The Genealogical Adam and Eve' (2019). This work challenges traditional evangelical views on creation by proposing a model that reconciles evolutionary science with a historical Adam and Eve, suggesting that they could be genealogical ancestors of all living humans. His approach has sparked considerable debate within evangelical circles, engaging interlocutors such as William Lane Craig and John Walton. Swamidass's work is characterized by its interdisciplinary nature, drawing on genetics, theology, and philosophy to address complex questions about human origins. He is also the founder of Peaceful Science, an organization dedicated to fostering dialogue between scientists and religious communities. Swamidass's contributions are distinctive for their emphasis on genealogical ancestry as a framework for understanding human origins, which has implications for theological anthropology and the doctrine of original sin. His work continues to influence contemporary discussions on the compatibility of faith and science, positioning him as a pivotal figure in evangelical thought.

timeline.event: Continues as Associate Professor at Washington University in St. Louis

themes.label: Genealogical Ancestry
themes.gloss: Swamidass introduces the concept of genealogical ancestry to reconcile evolutionary science with the theological narrative of Adam and Eve. He argues that genealogical ancestry allows for a historical Adam and Eve who are ancestors of all living humans, without contradicting the scientific consensus on human evolution.

themes.label: Science and Faith Dialogue
themes.gloss: Swamidass is a prominent figure in the dialogue between science and faith, advocating for a peaceful coexistence and mutual enrichment of both domains. His work emphasizes the importance of interdisciplinary engagement and seeks to bridge gaps between scientific and religious communities.

themes.label: Theological Anthropology
themes.gloss: Through his work, Swamidass contributes to theological anthropology by exploring the implications of genealogical ancestry for understanding human nature, original sin, and the image of God. His approach challenges traditional evangelical views and offers a nuanced perspective on human origins.

name: Andrew Wilson
bio: Andrew Wilson is a prominent contemporary evangelical theologian and pastor known for his articulate engagement with charismatic theology and biblical hermeneutics. Born in 1978, Wilson has become a significant voice within the evangelical tradition, particularly through his role at King's Church London. His theological development has been marked by a robust dialogue with both classical and contemporary thinkers, including N.T. Wright and John Piper. Wilson's work often addresses the intersection of charismatic experience and scriptural authority, a theme evident in his writings such as 'Spirit and Sacrament' and 'Unbreakable: What the Son of God Said About the Word of God.' He has been involved in various controversies, notably his defense of charismatic gifts within a broadly evangelical framework, which has sometimes placed him at odds with cessationist perspectives. Wilson's distinctive contributions include a nuanced approach to the authority of Scripture, emphasizing its narrative coherence and Christocentric focus. His engagement with the New Testament's portrayal of Jesus has been particularly influential, as seen in his co-authored book 'Echoes of Exodus,' which explores biblical typology. Wilson's theological work is characterized by a commitment to both intellectual rigor and pastoral sensitivity, making him a key figure in contemporary evangelical discourse.

timeline.event: Joined King's Church London as a teaching pastor

themes.label: Charismatic Theology
themes.gloss: Wilson advocates for the integration of charismatic gifts within evangelical worship, arguing for their biblical validity and contemporary relevance. His work challenges cessationist views by emphasizing the continuity of spiritual gifts as a means of edification and mission.

themes.label: Biblical Hermeneutics
themes.gloss: Wilson's approach to Scripture is marked by a narrative and Christocentric hermeneutic. He stresses the importance of understanding the Bible as a unified story centered on Christ, advocating for a reading that appreciates both historical context and theological depth.

themes.label: Christology
themes.gloss: In his exploration of New Testament Christology, Wilson emphasizes the typological connections between the Old and New Testaments. His work highlights the continuity of God's redemptive plan through Jesus, as seen in his analysis of biblical typology in 'Echoes of Exodus.'

name: Ben C. Blackwell
bio: Ben C. Blackwell is a contemporary theologian known for his contributions to Pauline studies and the intersection of theology and biblical exegesis. As an Associate Professor of Early Christianity at Houston Baptist University, Blackwell has engaged deeply with the works of the Apostle Paul, particularly focusing on the theological implications of Paul's writings. His scholarship often dialogues with the New Perspective on Paul, engaging with figures such as N.T. Wright and James D.G. Dunn, while also considering the traditional Reformed interpretations. Blackwell's work is characterized by a commitment to understanding the historical context of early Christianity and its theological developments. He has contributed to the discourse on theosis, exploring how Pauline theology can be understood in light of this concept traditionally associated with Eastern Orthodoxy. His publications, including 'Christosis: Pauline Soteriology in Light of Deification in Irenaeus and Cyril of Alexandria,' reflect his interest in the patristic interpretations of Paul and their relevance for contemporary theology. Blackwell's approach is marked by a synthesis of historical-critical methods and theological reflection, aiming to bridge the gap between academic biblical studies and ecclesial theology. His work continues to influence both scholarly and ecclesiastical circles, contributing to a nuanced understanding of Pauline theology in the modern context.

timeline.event: Published 'Christosis: Pauline Soteriology in Light of Deification in Irenaeus and Cyril of Alexandria'

themes.label: Pauline Soteriology
themes.gloss: Blackwell explores the concept of soteriology within Paul's writings, particularly focusing on the theme of 'Christosis' or deification, drawing connections between Pauline theology and patristic interpretations.
